SPEECH.SPEAKER: Lloyd Mr B.

TALK.START.PARA: —I wish to speak on three matters concerning the Department of Aviation-cost recovery, airworthiness surveyors, and Badgerys Creek. All of them are very sad cases for the Department. As to cost recovery, a dramatic increase has been forced on the operators of all forms of aircraft in this country through the Government's rejection of a 10-year phased-in cost recovery arrangement as recommended by the Bosch Inquiry into Aviation Cost Recovery, which suggested, at the same time, that there would be a considerable increase in the efficiency of the Department of Aviation. At this stage, the full cost recovery will come in one year. For commuter airline operators-that is, regional airline operators-that has meant some dramatic increases. For example, one operator has gone from $96,000 last year to $220,000 this year, and that includes the 50 per cent subsidy which the Minister for Aviation (Mr Peter Morris) has so generously granted for one year. Next year, the figure will move to at least $440,000. Another operator has gone from $32,000 last year to $126,000 this year, and next year the figure will be $250,000. The short haul commuters are the hardest hit because of the greater number of movements. Regional communities are particularly hard hit because it is their air services that are affected.

SPEECH.PARA: General aviation will also be hit. There is no increase this year because of the dual running arrangement. The Department must establish an accounting system so that the new charges can be brought in next year. I ask the Minister how that is to be done. I have been told that additional staff are being employed on a temporary basis at airports around Australia-one here and a couple there-all of whom manually record all airways movements so they can try to work out something for next year. Is that the case? If so, how much is it costing, and will it be an added charge for cost recovery for those unfortunate people in general aviation when they are hit with the increase next year?

The Minister has indicated that because of the increase in fuel excise the 100 per cent cost recovery has been able to be met in one year because it has been there on an attributive basis. What happens as the world oil price increases as it will over a period and the excise falls as it has already? This will mean that what appeared to be the very dramatic but nevertheless final increase in costs for cost recovery will not actually be so. On the matter of cost recovery, the Department has stated that one of the reasons why it needs so much money is that it has a responsibility to maintain air safety. Only on Wednesday in this Parliament the Minister referred to the Bankstown Airport and to the important role of airworthiness surveyors in maintaining safety. They check maintenance procedures. That is good for Bankstown and New South Wales. What about Victoria and the Tasmanian region? The Department has not replaced, resigned or retired surveyors. A letter was sent from the Department last month to all operators of aircraft in Victoria saying that there would be delays in airworthiness surveyors, work and that they should go out and hire private industry people to do the work that they are supposedly already paying for through cost recovery in the Department. So they will be forced to make a double payment. So much for the Department and its efficiency and overall priority for maintaining safety.

The union covering airworthiness surveyors has imposed a ban and has had restrictive work practices in place. There has been no word of this from the Department. It has been selectively saying with whom it will carry out the surveys. It is a blatant, restrictive work practice. The union sent a letter to all the operators in Victoria last month telling them that it may have dropped its ban in relation to Moorabbin but from now on it will decide who will be surveyed. Instead of about 20 man days a month being made available for this sort of work the union is keeping it down to about 12 days a month. One has to ask the Minister: Who is running the Department? Is the Department running anybody, or is the union saying what will be done and what will not be done? Meanwhile the commuter airlines and general aviation are suffering both in cost and in potential danger. I want to move on to an even bigger problem--

TALK.START.PARA: —Four for every registered aircraft.

—I thank the honourable member. There is an even bigger problem; that is the tragedy of broken promises at Badgerys Creek. In February this year the Minister announced the selection of Badgerys Creek as the site for the second Sydney airport. A glossy publication has been put out by the Department entitled `Second Sydney Airport, Final Site Selection'. It states:

SPEECH.PARA: Existing property owners or business owners will be invited to sell their properties at a time which is convenient to themselves, their families, or, where appropriate, their business partners.
Each property or business will be valued individually by qualified valuers and the sale price offered will be market value.
In a letter from the Minister dated 24 February, addressed to all landholders, it is stated:
In other words, you can sell your land to the Commonwealth right now and I can guarantee that you will get a fair market price as determined by the independent government valuer.
You can negotiate the sale of your property to the Commonwealth any time up until the stage where the land is actually required for development.

So far so good. We commend the Minister for that type of follow-up. The people at Badgerys Creek were obviously unhappy because they were the unfortunate ones in that area and had properties where the new airport site was to be situated. But there was to be a reasonable and fair arrangement. However, by 25 July the Minister put out a statement restricting that open ended type of arrangement whereby the people who were affected could sell whenever they wished. In other words, all bets were off from those nice opening days. A total of $9.5m was allocated in the Budget for compensation, but 240 landholders within the boundaries are affected and are eligible for compensation. That is not including a further group outside the boundary but within the noise exposure area where living will be impossible.

So the Dear John letter came on August 26 from the Chief Property Officer in New South Wales saying that only approximately 44 properties, for which firm arrangements had been made, could be accommodated within the $9 1/2m. Even that is doubtful. The total compensation bill will obviously be somewhere between $75m and $100m. That means that those people directly affected will have to wait up to seven or perhaps 10 years to be treated. That is not all. These people were promised independent private valuations if they wanted to go that way. But the August letter cancelled that, and the independent valuations, I am told by the local people, were up to $30,000 better than the Government valuations. But that is still not all, because not all of the Government valuers have been actually registered or licensed in New South Wales, and there is an investigation by the New South Wales Real Estate Valuers Registration Board at present. But even that is still not all, because a letter by the Minister on 19 September 1985 to one of the landholders outside the immediate compensatable area said:
. . . concerns in regard to your property . . . will be dealt with in a fair and equitable manner.

Later on it is found that they will not be eligible at all. The Minister must accept responsibility for these broken promises and for the ruined lives of these people. They cannot sell; they are not even allowed to alter their buildings because a freeze has been imposed by the Council. Business is falling in the area; marriages are failing. There is no ability to plan and the prospect of up to a 10-year wait. To add insult to injury, the locals claim that the re-letting of some of those properties that have been acquired is at a rate better than it should be in relation to the compensation price. In other words, the Government is doing well. But there were two final insults. Within the last two weeks there have been phone calls to the Minister's office from affected people. Those who phoned from the area outside immediate compensation were told: `We dropped you because if we did anything to help you Bruce Lloyd would jump up and down in Parliament about it'. People who made phone calls to the Minister's office from inside that area were told: `Because you went to the media we will not look after you as well as we might have otherwise'. So the Minister has a few problems on his hands. He should accept his responsibilities and look after these people. He should not with those sorts of comments from his office fob off people with genuine problems.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Darling Mrs E.E.

TALK.START.PARA: —I rise in this Committee debate to speak on matters within the portfolios of Transport and Aviation. I do so with some pleasure. These are areas of crucial importance to the economic security and safety of the Australian people, and I have a particular interest in policy implications arising from their administration. In particular, I am concerned about safety issues associated with transport and I am pleased, as a member of the Hawke Government, to reflect on the achievements and initiatives undertaken not only in this year's Budget but in all previous years in office-brought about, as they were, under the ministry of our most energetic Minister for Transport and Minister for Aviation (Mr Peter Morris).

SPEECH.PARA: In the area of road safety, there is a complex set of factors associated with the advancement of what must be, and is, an effective policy. These include: Road user education; road user attitudes, which is another most important aspect; the correct enforcement of traffic rules, because there is not a lot of good in having the rules if they are not properly enforced; and the effective use of available facilities. It is a matter of making the tax dollar go as far as we can.

However, these factors, while being within the responsibilities of governments, are to a large extent affected only indirectly by Federal policy. In the construction of a direct causal relationship between deliberate policy and road safety advancement, very little can be seen to have a greater impact than the construction and maintenance of a comprehensive road system. Road funding has been a noteworthy achievement of the Hawke Government and, as such, has contributed greatly to the improved welfare and safety of Australians. Since coming to office, this Government has increased Federal road funding by 82 per cent. That is no mean achievement. This has meant an increase in real terms over the life of this Government of over 26 per cent. The greatest individual increase has been in the funding of arterial roads which, despite being primarily a State responsibility, has increased by 31 per cent in real terms.

I would like to stress this point because I want to indicate the position of Federal road funding as it affects my home State of Queensland. Despite the continued bleatings of the Premier of Queensland, that State has actually done extremely well through the road funding policies of the Hawke Government. I am pleased to say that Queensland has received an 85 per cent increase in Federal road funds since the last full year of the Fraser Government. Queensland's allocation of Federal funding has increased by 26 per cent in real terms since the election of the Hawke Government. Queensland has enjoyed the greatest increase in respect of Federal roads of any State since the Hawke Government came to office. Queensland has enjoyed the second highest increase of any State in respect of national and local roads and the third highest increase in respect of arterial roads. In addition, the national highway program has been an enormously successful Federal commitment in Queensland, with 67 separate projects undertaken last financial year across the State.

It is amazing that we should ever hear any word, any squeak from the Queensland Government and those who wish to attack us about road funding when one considers that there has been an 85 per cent increase-not five, 10 or 15 per cent-in Federal road funds for Queensland since we took over from the Fraser Government. One can see that Queensland in particular has benefited from the enlightened and socially responsible road funding policies of the Hawke Government. The Queensland Government should have the guts to say so. The benefits that Queensland has received will be felt by all road users as the expansion and upgrading of our roads is the most tangible and effective course of action available to any government in making road use safer and in reducing the road toll.

I make the comment here that random breath testing is another highly successful means of keeping our roads safer. Full random breath testing has been introduced in Victoria, South Australia, Tasmania, New South Wales and the Northern Territory and it has a fine deterrent effect. Many people in Queensland-74 per cent of Queenslanders responded to a survey by the Brisbane media, Drug Arm and Brisbane's Lord Mayor on this matter which goes beyond party politics-would agree with me that we urgently need to see random breath testing given a go in Queensland. We can only hope that now an election campaign is under way, the Premier of Queensland may decide at last to put people before other interests.

One can see that under a progressive, committed government, such as the present Federal Government, the huge social and economic costs of road crashes can be reduced. It has been estimated that road crashes cost the community over $3 billion every year. That monetary cost is compounded by the human cost of death and injury to our fellow Australians. It is beyond costing. In this context, the Federal Government has sought to explore every possible means of advancing road safety. Apart from the actual construction and maintenance of the roads, this has included new certification arrangements to ensure vehicle safety standards, programs to increase community awareness and involvement in the issue of road safety and encouragement of and co-operation with State governments and interested groups in the development of new methods of advancing road safety.

Specifically, these initiatives have included research based high profile promotions such as the Molly Meldrum bicycle helmet campaign and the out and about campaign for school children, which was very well received in Queensland; the national road safety symposium, which was an effective forum for the presentation of road safety issues for discussion within the Australian community and which showed the high priority given by this Federal Government to national road safety; the national road freight industry inquiry; and the Bikesafe 86 conference held in New-castle earlier this year to discuss issues relating to bicycle safety, which is a major area of concern. These and many other Federal initiatives are making a vital contribution to the struggle for improved road safety.

Clearly, there are signs that the situation is improving. Since 1983, the first year of the Hawke Government, there has been a 12.6 per cent decrease in the yearly total of road fatalities. I am sure that people across the board welcome this decrease. In that year the number of Australians killed on roads fell to below 3,000 for the first time since 1964. Encouragingly, this total has so far again failed to rise above 3,000. To the extent that we can expend the funds, we in the Federal Government will do all that we can to see that this horrific toll continues to decrease. We must not, however, rest on the laurels of such encouraging trends. There is much to do, and in the current climate of restraint, economic considerations impinge on necessary and clear policy goals. The Government has responded not only by maintaining its funding of road safety programs but also by greatly improving the efficiency of money spent. In this year's Budget overall Federal spending on road safety increased by 8.9 per cent. However, operational and administrative costs were brought down by 6.2 per cent. That figure appears in the Budget Papers and that achievement deserves consideration.

TALK.START.PARA: —A great achievement.

—Money spent on programs will increase by over 26 per cent and, as my colleague said, is a great achievement. It represents a fitting testimony of this Government's ability to address its road safety commitments within the context of necessary and responsible economic management. This year's Budget once again shows how the Hawke Government is taking positive steps in the direction of greater road safety.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Lindsay Mr E.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I intend to address my remarks in this debate to the issue of transport, particularly shipping and road transport. Australia carries 3 per cent or less of its external trade in Australian ships. That is bad for the Australian economy because 97 per cent of our external sea freight trade, amounting to billions of dollars, is in the hands of foreign owners. There is an adverse impact on Australia's balance of payments. The net impact upon our foreign exchange bill of using a foreign flag ship as against an Australian flag ship, in very rough figures, is $1m per ship per year. Some people may say that $1m per ship per year is not a lot of money, but when it is multiplied by the number of ships needed to handle our external trade it becomes a very big amount indeed.

SPEECH.PARA: In 1984-85 there were 6,760 overseas vessel calls at Australian ports. Total freight paid in 1984-85 was $6.7 billion and of that sum $5.8 billion was paid to foreigners. The transport portion of our balance of payments deficit, at $2.124 billion, is around 20 per cent of our total deficit on current account. In terms of tonne kilometres Australia is the fifth largest user of sea transport in the world. Dr Ian Storey in a recent paper to the Economic Society of Australia said:

If higher priority were placed on using Australian shipping facilities it is not inconceivable that the transport deficit could be eliminated by the end of the decade, given that Australian shipping credits are already $2.85 billion and growing compared with shipping debits of $5 billion.

He claimed that transport accounts were 21 per cent of the invisibles deficit. The Chairman of the Australian National Maritime Association, Mr Bill Bolitho, recently observed that there is a fundamental reason why Australian commerce is at the mercy of our sophisticated trading partners with respect to the invisibles of freight and insurance other than our own problems. He said that, as a colony of the British-then the greatest maritime nation on earth-we were never allowed to develop a commercial culture in which Australian shipping could develop. The British kept it to themselves. From the early navigation Acts of 1651 through to the merchant shipping Acts of the nineteenth century and almost to modern times, the British controlled the maritime commerce of their colonies. That is why we are only just now as a nation waking up to the importance of freight to the national economy. Even the Australian Chamber of Shipping is controlled by foreign shipowners whose fundamental interests cannot but be opposed to our own, and successive governments of both political persuasions have looked to it for advice on Australian shipping.

One of the craziest proposals ever put forward in this Parliament was contained in a Bill introduced into the Senate by Senator Hamer to repeal coasting trade provisions of the Navigation Act 1912. The Bill proposed the deregulation of the Australian coastal shipping industry. If passed, the Bill would permit foreign shipping to operate Australia's coastal shipping trade. Present legislation, which has been in operation for more than 60 years, ensures that Australian coastal trade is carried in vessels that are Australian owned or controlled and crewed by Australians. Australia is not the only country in which coastal trade is carried mostly by national flag carriers. Countries which reserve their coastal trade for their own ships include the United States of America, Canada, New Zealand, France, Germany, Greece, India, Italy, Spain, Brazil, Chile, Indonesia and Malaysia.

The Liberal-National Party policy to introduce foreign flag ships to Australian coastal trade would simply reduce the Australian value added content of what Australia makes, consumes and exports. Under this stupid and illogical policy of the Liberal and National parties we might as well have Korean politicians, Indian judges and Taiwanese postmen. The answers to the problems of the shipping industry do not lie in abandoning the Australian coastal shipping industry to foreign vessels.

In 1986 the Minister for Transport (Mr Peter Morris) received the `Liner Shipping Report-an Industry Task Force Review of Australian Overseas Liner Shipping Legislation'. The major recommendation of the report, which relates to changes in Australian Government legislation, is the call for an Australian shipping Act. The proposed Australian shipping Act would provide a unique framework for liner shipping, yet would be consistent with the pro-competitive philosophy of the Trade Practices Act. Foreign controlled shipping cartel arrangements would be opened up to greater scrutiny. The Act would be compatible with the multilateral framework of liner shipping and legislation of our major trading partners. I understand that after a similar liner shipping review in the United States of America in 1984 a separate shipping Act was introduced and the European Economic Community is close to introducing a similar instrument. It would follow that it is entirely appropriate for Australia to establish a separate and distinguishable shipping Act similar to our major trading partners, which deals with the complex framework of liner shipping existing today.

The Australian Shippers Council for some years has strongly advocated such a separate shipping Act. The report further recommended that the Australian shipping Act should safeguard the competitive access of national flag ship owners to an equitable share of cargoes and ensure that Australian labour has reasonable continuity of employment opportunities under internationally accepted conditions. This recommendation has been misconstrued by some to mean that the proposed Australian shipping Act would provide for exclusive cargo shares for national flag or Australian flag ships, but that is a deliberate distortion of the liner shipping report recommendations.

The Hawke Government's policy with respect to shipping has resulted in improvements in Australian flag shipping. It has had the effect of reducing the freight rate for iron ore from Port Hedland to Newcastle by 50 per cent and from Port Hedland to Port Kembla by 30 per cent between 1982 and the present. Without the co-operation of the maritime trade unions and the resultant efficiencies in Australian flag shipping, the steel works at Newcastle would have closed. I congratulate the Minister for Transport on his enlightened approach to developing a shipping policy and shipping legislation that will restore the Australian shipping industry to a level which will serve not only the commercial interests of our nation but also our strategic interests.

I would like to say a few words about road transport. The most important road in my electorate of Herbert is the Bruce Highway. Named after a former Queensland Minister for Public Works, the Hon. H. A. Bruce, it stretches 1,690 kilometres from Brisbane to Cairns. The bitumen link from Brisbane to Cairns was completed in 1962, although the Bruce Highway itself was not fully sealed until October 1982 when the road between Marlborough and St Lawrence was completed. The Bruce Highway was declared a national highway in 1974 by the Whitlam Labor Government. In 1982 a joint Federal-State government study - -

They get off the planes, go down the gangways and have to wait to go through the Customs and immigration inspections, but there are no chairs for them to sit on. There is a lack of shopping facilities, baggage handling facilities and information. Some people who come off aircraft know they are in Australia but they do not know where. They look around desperately for a map or some information to tell them what they can do next.
—Hopeless! They have a terminal problem.

—It is hopeless and it is very serious. We have the great potential of this industry to bring people to Australia, and it is growing week by week, yet when the people get here we have these inadequate facilities. One must wonder whether the Government is serious about developing the tourist industry. The private sector is playing its part which is a very important role. Billions of dollars are going into tourist facilities in this country. Yet the Government sector, when it comes to airport facilities, is not playing its part. The Australian Tourist Commission is being given some $30m of Government money this year and is spending it effectively overseas. We have the enormous bonus promotions of films like Crocodile Dundee in America from where many of our tourists are now coming and will come.
—A great film.

—It is a great film and it is a bonus; there is no government money in that. It provides millions and millions of dollars of free publicity for this country. Yet when people get here they are faced with these inadequate facilities. Is there a solution? Of course there is; there is always a solution to major problems. If the Government cannot provide the money or will not acknowledge the priorities that the airport facilities demand, why not let the private sector get involved? When the Minister responds I would like him to answer that question. He has had proposals put to him in relation to Darwin and Brisbane to get the private sector involved, to build these facilities and to assist the Government in providing some export income to this country at a time when we desperately need it and when we have a godsent opportunity to develop this enormous tourism industry. For some reason which escapes me and which I think escapes everyone on this side of the House the proposals are put forward but they are knocked back. One can only assume that a socialist government is so terrified of letting things slip out of its hands and terrified that somehow it will lose control that it will not let the private sector get involved.

SPEECH.PARA: Because of the inadequate facilities in Sydney, Qantas is to go to the Government with a proposal involving some $20m. Mr Stainlay told a recent Price Waterhouse seminar that, if the plans for Sydney Airport are not large enough to cope with visitor growth projections, alternative private development plans would eventuate. He said that Qantas had had discussions with businessmen who were prepared to commit up to $20m privately to develop a new terminal at the airport. He also said that these plans might be put into action if current Government plans prove not to be adequate. Why were the Brisbane plans of the Moore consortium knocked back? There was the Darwin proposal for private sector involvement, and a Qantas proposal will be put before the Minister. Why, when we have this great problem, will the Minister not allow the private sector to become involved?

An important matter for the aviation industry is the British travel agents' convention which will be held in Australia in November. As I understand the proposal that has been put to the Minister, Qantas and British Airways would carry those attending the convention across Australia in a domestic sense and deposit them on the eastern seaboard-in Brisbane or, presumably, near the Gold Coast. I understand also that Ansett Airlines of Australia and Australian Airlines have agreed that because of the congestion experienced by domestic airlines in November, and bearing in mind that about 4,000 agents will be attending the convention, they would not object to some limited interlining, if that is the correct phrase, taking place. As I understand it, yet again the Minister has said no to the proposal. I and thousands of others would be very interested to know why the Minister has again been so negative in denying the free carriage of these people across Australia to attend an enormously important convention on the Gold Coast.

Tourism is probably our largest industry and it is the one that shows most signs of growth. It is the one industry that in the short term future can assist to get this country out of a hell of an economic mess. I ask the Minister to consider the proposals that are being put before him to improve our international airport facilities and to stop being so negative. I ask him to give the tourist industry the chance to progress that it should have.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Mildren Mr J.B.

TALK.START.PARA: —I shall address my comments to Australian shipping. For far too long Australia has been beholden to the owners of foreign shipping for the export of Australian goods. As the honourable member for Herbert (Mr Lindsay) said, this is part and parcel of the cultural cringe of this country. In the past, when Australia was a British colony-we have never really recovered from those days in this respect-Britain was able to gain an extra income by using its own shipping in the course of trade with this country. This has left Australia in a very unenviable position. Even today, the exports carried by Australian shipping constitute a minute percentage of our total seaborne exports. In 1984-85, this traffic amounted to only 3 per cent and that is something that should come as a bit of a shock to most Australians. In other words, 97 per cent of Australia's seaborne exports were carried by foreign shipping lines. This is an alarming and frustrating picture, especially when it is seen in the context of Australia's total export trade.

SPEECH.PARA: In the financial year 1984-85, for which we have complete figures, 269 million tonnes of freight, or 99 per cent of our total exports, were exported by sea. Only 3 per cent of this tonnage was carried by Australian-owned shipping. Some important facts should be impressed upon Parliament and the nation about our exports because the significance of this trade is relevant to Australia and to the rest of the world. Australia is now the world's largest exporter of coal with 83.7 million tonnes being exported in 1984-85. There were 718,000 tonnes of wool exported in 1984-85. We are the second largest iron ore exporter-we are behind Brazil-with 91.2 million tonnes being exported in 1984-85. In the same year, we exported 558,000 tonnes of meat. In that instance we took second place to the European Economic Community. We are the second largest seaborne grain exporter, exporting 22.4 million tonnes in 1984-85 and taking second place to the United States of America. We are among the top five exporters in the world of a number of other minerals and metals.

To emphasise the tremendous importance of shipping to Australia as a trading-exporting nation and our reliance upon shipping because of our remoteness we should bear in mind that in terms of the seaborne transport task based upon the volume or cargo and distance carried, Australia ranks about the fifth largest user in the world behind Japan, the United States, Saudi Arabia and the Netherlands. I tire of hearing those in Australia who do not believe that Australians can do as well as, if not better than, those in other nations in whatever task they set themselves. Our recent record as a shipping nation puts the lie to that view. When the Minister for Transport (Mr Morris) took office, the industry was in a parlous state. However, under his responsible leadership there is now evolving a climate of confidence and competence in the industry. His efforts demonstrate clearly what can happen when all parties are prepared to meet in an atmosphere of purposeful co-operation. Government, employers and unions have been prepared to examine their own roles with a view to making the necessary changes in their attitudes, practices and their previously perceived log of interests in order to provide the optimum conditions for the industry to become competitive.

That this effort has borne fruit can be amply demonstrated when one considers the results for 1985-86. For example, Australian National Line returned an operating profit for the year of $33.2m. The transport division of the Broken Hill Proprietary Co. Ltd. has contributed $30m to the overall profit of BHP last year. These results have come in extremely difficult times but we have a minor competitive edge. To emphasise this, it should be said that Australian exporters and importers are benefiting from the current record low freight rates which have resulted from the continued oversupply of shipping and intense competition on the world's shipping routes. Both spot and longer term bulk freight rates have shown dramatic reductions since their peak in 1980. They are now as low as 30 per cent of peak rates in some trades and they are not expected to increase in the near future as the oversupply of shipping is likely to continue. The liner freight rates for meat and wool to main destinations are lower in real terms, after adjustment for inflation, than they were 10 years ago. The average in-bound liner freight rates have declined significantly since 1981. In some major trades they have declined by up to 40 per cent.

It has to be recognised that there has been a severe decline in the fortunes of some of the major shipping lines. In recent years, 25 lines with direct services to and from Australia have collapsed. The profits made by ANL and BHP have come in a period when many other operators have been forced to rationalise their services, to withhold dividends or to take substantial losses. It is exceedingly frustrating to have to accept that so much of our seaborne export trade has been concentrated in the hands of the off-shore dominated lines. As at 30 June 1986, 33 vessels were operating in the Australian overseas trading fleet. This includes 12 bulk carriers, five tankers and 16 general or special purpose cargo vessels. I emphasise once again that only 3 per cent of our total seaborne trade was carried by this fleet compared with the 34 per cent that was carried by Japanese flag ships, 19 per cent by flag of convenience carriers and 5 per cent by the ships of centrally planned economies.

It is astonishing that in the areas of major tonnages, the bulk trades, our share has been exceedingly low. For example, in the carriage of coal our share was just over one per cent. Nevertheless, it is a great achievement for ANL to increase its participation rate within the liner conference trades from 15 per cent to 24 per cent in the European trade and to 35 per cent in the Asian trade.

Due regard should be given to the determined effort of Broken Hill Proprietary Co. Ltd to gain a larger slice of the coal trade with Japan and Korea. In this highly competitive market, BHP has installed three major carriers. The Iron Newcastle and the Iron Kembla are each 147,000 tonnes dead-weight in the Japan trade. The Iron Pacific, of 232,000 tonnes dead-weight, in the Korea trade, is the largest twin-screw craft in the world, and a state of the art ship.

We look forward to seeing significant growth in our total coal export trade to 3 per cent. That is a 200 per cent increase; it is still not what one would call huge as a parcel of our export trade of coal. That will still be only a 6.6 per cent increase, or a 42.7 million tonnes increase, in five years.

In order to increase the efficiency of our shipping, the companies have begun using a triangular service pattern which combines coal exports and coastal movement of iron ore. We cannot ignore the importance of developing our export oriented shipping lines. As much as anything, we should recognise that the current reliance on off-shore owned shipping for our export trade has a serious impact on our balance of payments. It is estimated that, each year, the invisible cost of freight charges is nearly $7,000m. In 1984-85, Australia paid out nearly 87 per cent of total trade related freight earnings, both sea and air, to foreign earners. The amount was $5,806m. That enormous amount of money should have been coming our way. We must set ourselves that target.

Insurance, agents' fees and commissions are also invisibles that must, in truth, be charged against the balance of payments, resulting in an increased deficit. We must increase our encouragement for Australian shipping lines to increase their share of the export market.

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! The honourable member's time has expired.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Millar Mr P.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —Some very worthwhile contributions have been made in the brief opportunities for honourable members to speak at the Committee stage of Appropriation Bill (No. 1). The honourable member for Ballarat (Mr Mildren) touched on something that could well demand the attention of the Committee to a greater extent than is possible at present. He made a perfectly valid point. We have trading balance difficulties. Month by month and year by year we are losing extraordinary sums of money, not just with the shipping of exports but on the shipping of imports, because they are costed in foreign exchange. I think that that demand should command the more urgent attention of this Parliament to produce a much more accommodating result.

SPEECH.PARA: This morning I wished to speak on matters that have been accommodated, to some extent, by other speakers. It seemed trite to say that Australia is a big country, and because of its sparsity of population and relatively small population in total, very substantial costs arise in giving reasonable service to those people throughout our country who have reasonable expectations. Clearly, as was mentioned this morning, it is beyond the resources of our country in terms of taxpayers' direct contributions. Particularly, I refer to our international airport terminal facilities. In a number of strategic points in Australia, there is little prospect-I say this with all fairness-of government providing, through ordinary revenue resources, the money to meet the requirements. Whilst there may be philosophical differences, I think that strong argument can be advanced to permit private enterprise to come in and fill the shortfall on terms that are thoroughly acceptable to the government of the day. The alternative is that we will make little, if any, progress. I have very much in mind, when I say that, the Sydney international airport terminal building. The Minister for Aviation (Mr Peter Morris) will immediately recognise that I have had an involvement in another area on that matter. We are presently proposing to spend $20m to build-in redundancy. On the admission of the Department of Aviation witnesses before a Public Works Committee inquiry, it was acknowledged that, under the proposal, at the end of three years of renovation and alteration, the Sydney international airport terminal building will be as congested as it is now, if not more congested.

TALK.START.PARA: —No improvement.

—There will be no improvement, and it could be worse. That is a quite bizarre situation. Perhaps the Minister is influenced to some extent by the establishment of the Federal Airports Corporation, which can take over the problem. But why compound the difficulties confronting the Corporation by pre-empting a decision it may make in these matters to initiate works on a terminal that will leave it as inadequate, if not more inadequate, when the works are completed?

SPEECH.PARA: The honourable member for McPherson (Mr White) said that Qantas Airways Ltd has offered to build a terminal free of cost to the Government. I must admit that I have an instinctive aversion to letting such critical areas of operation out of the hands, by way of direct control, of the Government. I see aviation as a sensitive area where safety is a dominant consideration. In real terms, I see no reason why the proposal cannot be accommodated. After all, the Government is in a position to determine what arrangement may be entered into. It need not forgo its responsibilities as it sees them in terms of safety and maintaining control of the airport. It is simply a building. If private enterprise can see an opportunity to advance its own interests while meeting in full the expectations and entitlements of the travelling public and the Government in terms of its responsibilities, there would be some merit attaching to an earnest address to the possibilities inherent in such a proposal.

With burgeoning tourism, we cannot have tourists departing our shores and becoming counter-ambassadors for Australia. The word will get around very quickly. The honourable member for Fadden (Mr Jull) canvassed very adequately the position at the Brisbane international airport terminal building. He omitted to mention one point. I do not say that in any critical way. There is an expression of view that aircraft integrity could suffer as a result of the extraordinary length of taxi-ing an aircraft from the new Brisbane airport, when it comes into commission, to the existing international airport terminal building which will continue to be used, under present Government plans, for some considerable time. Aircraft could overheat, suffer brake damage, and so on. The proposal leaves a lot to be desired. Perish the thought of what will happen if Brisbane is successful in securing the Olympic Games. Tourism, which offers so much hope for Australia with its budgetary difficulties, should not be impeded in the least for the want of adequate facilities.

The Federal Airports Corporation will benefit, hopefully, from the transfer of 1,600 staff from the Department of Aviation. It is to be hoped that those staff, moving into a new environment, will be imbued with a sense of purpose and a spirit of resolve which will dispel what, sadly, seems to be the view of a wide section of the community, that the Department, under the mantle of safety requirements, is left to perform in a manner not necessarily consistent with that which is expected of it and, in fact, that which it should achieve. I hope that the transfer of 1,600 staff will produce a result which, in a very brief period, will dispel that notion which, sadly, reflects on the Department.

Deregulation of our internal airlines is a highly topical issue. At first blush it has a great deal to commend it. But as one with a very modest flying experience as a pilot of modest stature, I am mindful that the pre-eminent requirement is safety. It cannot be tampered with. It cannot be set aside to wait a better day when it could be addressed as it should be addressed. My concern with deregulation is that in the very nature of operations one cannot expect an airline at 5 p.m. on a sunny Thursday to decide that it is no longer viable and will withdraw from operations on Friday morning. That would be an absurdity. The reality of the matter is that there is a shadowy period where the grim realisation that they are no longer viable descends upon airlines and they strive to maintain viability.

We get these tragic situations evident in the United States of America as a product of de- regulation where airlines have cut corners. They have done all sorts of things that impinge absolutely and irrevocably on air safety. That concerns me. If we embark boldly on a philosophical act for deregulation, certainly there is considerable scope to improve upon our two-airlines system. Competition is a great stimulus and there is a mutuality of benefit attaching to that particular circumstance. But it is something that must be pursued. It must be done with extreme caution and responsibility. We should not necessarily let the market-place resolve the issue because very substantial risks attach to that. We should certainly address that matter further.

In Australia we have runs on the board in many respects with operational safety, innovative devices and systems to ensure the well-being of passengers, crew and aircraft. I still remain totally fascinated with the simplicity of the T-VASIS system to ensure constant gradient approaches for airports. It is absolutely foolproof and so simple. I always feel proud about it when I realise that it is an Australian invention. I thank you, Mr Mountford, for the brief opportunity to say a few words on matters that are of more than passing concern to me. I am sure that the Minister, to the limit that he is able, will seriously address the propositions that have been put to him this morning.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Morris The Hon P.F.

TALKER.NAME: Mr PETER MORRIS
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Transport and Minister for Aviation)

TALK.START.PARA: —I thank all honourable members for participating in this morning's discussion. In summarising, first let me thank the honourable member for Lilley (Mrs Darling) who chairs the House of Representatives Standing Committee on Transport Safety. I commend her on her deep personal commitment to the improvement particularly of road safety. She raised, quite properly, the record road effort of this Government and the practised deception by the Queensland Government of Queenslanders in respect of the record road efforts by this Government.

SPEECH.PARA: We now have an election campaign under way in Queensland. The National Party of Australia is seeking to make Canberra bashing the principal issue. In the same policy speech delivered by the Premier of Queensland yesterday, the major plank is the work being funded 100 per cent by this Government on improving Queensland's road system. The simple facts are that 60 per cent of capital roadworks in Queensland are being paid for by this Government. Queenslanders know very well what a disastrous state their road system would be in today were it not for the efforts of this Government. On the one hand the Premier of Queensland is saying that Canberra is the problem in his State; on the other hand he is going to absolute extremes to conceal expenditure and improvements being paid for in full by this Government. That is the hallmark of that Government. The deception and corruption referred to by the Leader of the Liberal Party is the hallmark of the dying government in Queensland. The simple fact is that this Government in its short life has done more than any other government in the history of this nation in a comparable period to improve the road system of this country. We are proud of that achievement and we will carry on. The people of Queensland know that very well. They know that the improvements on the national highway link between Brisbane and Cairns are solely the result of the priorities and efforts of this Government. They have nought to do with the efforts of the Queensland Government which seeks only to deceive and to misrepresent.

The comments made by the honourable member for Herbert (Mr Lindsay) were, I thought, very useful and productive in the current debate about improving trade competitiveness. He pointed to the progress being made in improving the efficiency and the competitiveness of Australia's shipping industry. We have an abysmal rate of participation in the carriage of our international trades by sea. We are the fifth largest shipping market in the world and an isolated continent. When we look at our carriage of goods on a tonne-kilometre basis, we are the fifth largest market in the world. We ought to be the leading shipping nation in the world. This Government is determined that by improving our efficiency, or reliability and competitiveness we can gain a much greater share of that trade. We are doing that and it is being done on a co-operative and consultative basis, not in time of conflict but simply by consultation, negotiation and making progress, with everybody making a contribution.

The matter was further highlighted by the honourable member for Ballarat (Mr Mildren). As Chairman of the Government transport sub-committee, he has underlined the opportunity that exists for Australia to increase our foreign exchange earnings. I hope it is something that all members of the House will be supporting and looking to with pride, as did the honourable member for Wide Bay (Mr Millar). This is an area of activity where Australians, by their own endeavour and commitment, can improve greatly the participation in our sea transport.

Along with the comments of the honourable member for Herbert and the honourable member for Lilley in respect of the road efforts by this Government, what we are really doing with the national highway system is putting into place a quality sealed surface, flood-free standard national road grid that girdles Australia, that links Australia from the South to the North, that links Brisbane to Cairns and Burnie to Hobart in Tasmania and provides the means of road travel on easier, safer, quicker and cheaper conditions. If we are to exploit the benefits that are available from tourism that grid has to be in place. It contributes to improved transport efficiency and safer travel for these people who live in the regions which are traversed by the national highway system.

The honourable member for Murray (Mr Lloyd) referred to cost recovery. He made no mention of the role of the major airlines in the provision of air services or their contribution to cost recovery. What this Government has done in respect of aviation cost recovery is what no other government has been able to do; that is, it has introduced a system that places the cost burden of providing services to the industry on a much fairer basis. Those who use the service more make a greater contribution to the costs involved. That is essentially what the changes are about. No one can disagree with that. It is a fairer system.

In respect of general aviation, the honourable member referred to increases in costs for some operators, particularly commuter operators. It is true in percentage terms that these increases look large, but they are from a very small base in most cases. One can best judge the impact of these increased costs by referring to the increased fares that have resulted. Sunstate Airlines had a 1.5 per cent increase in air fares, Skywest Airlines Pty Ltd a one per cent increase and Hazelton Air Services Pty Ltd a $1.20 increase. Kendell Airways had a flag fall increase of $1.40. Airopelican Air Services Pty Ltd, an operation in my own electorate, had a 2.4 per cent increase and Airlines of Tasmania Pty Ltd a 3 per cent increase. Those approved air fare increases also took into account a 2.3 per cent increase in costs arising from the national wage decision. In respect of the other general aviation operators for whom changes have not been made, there was a 17 per cent increase, but that was the first increase for several years. Even then, the increase was considerably below the consumer price index increases over the same period. So no one can dispute that the system is fairer and that it is reasonable.

For general aviation, we have deferred the introduction of a new system until 1 July next year to enable the industry, at its request, to consult further with the Department and to put forward alternatives. No alternative has yet come forward, but I am sure that that will happen. Again, that has been done on the basis of consultation with the industry to try to develop a better and fairer system so that taxpayers who do not fly do not have to meet the costs of people who do. The honourable member referred also to the operation of the Department. Again, the critics who make such utterances as these ignore the fact that the Department of Aviation, by the end of this financial year, will have had a 6 per cent reduction in real terms in expenditure levels. There will have been a reduction of 1,200 in the number of employees over the period between March 1983 and 30 June 1986.

The ludicrous comparison is made-sometimes by people outside this place and sometimes by members of the Opposition, as occurred this morning-between the number of Department of Aviation employees per aircraft and the number of Federal Aviation Administration employees per aircraft in the United States of America. That is a nonsense comparison. It is a comparison of unlikes. It is a meaningless comparison because one must take into account the population, the density of traffic, the spread of services, and the location of population. But if one did want to make the comparison, for whatever reason, one should compare the Department of Aviation in Australia with the Federal Aviation Administration in the United States, those Department of State employees in the United States who carry on all the international negotiations, the National Transportation Safety Board in the United States, which does all the air safety investigation work, and the relevant division of the United States Department of Transportation. All of these bodies deal with matters handled by the Department of Aviation in this country. So it is ludicrous and insulting to the public of this country to make a comparison between the Federal Aviation Administration in the United States and the Department of Aviation in this country.

TALK.START.PARA: —And the economies of scale.

—Exactly. The economies of scale, the spread of population and the demand for services to be provided are all factors which have to be taken into account. This little bit of misinformation warms the egos of members of the Opposition and gives them an inner glow. But it is ludicrous to make that kind of comparison.

SPEECH.PARA: In respect of airworthiness surveyors, of which mention was made by the honourable member for Murray, the Department is aware of that problem. It is a short term difficulty that has arisen through the unexpected resignation of a number of airworthiness surveyors in Victoria. It is being addressed by the Department as quickly as possible. But the honourable member is totally wrong to suggest that the industry, through the payment of air navigation charges, is paying for airworthiness surveyor services that are not being provided. In fact, the air navigation charges go to recover the costs of providing airport and airway services, whereas the costs of airworthiness surveyors are met by the taxpayer and are currently not recovered from the industry. They are met by the taxpayer generally and will be met by regulatory service charges when they are introduced.

In respect of Badgery's Creek, the decision for a second Sydney airport site was one which the members of the Opposition when in government could never bring themselves to make. For year after year the previous Government fiddled and fiddled. This Government made that decision, and the rate of expressions of interest in negotiating for sale has been far greater than anything in history. In a matter of seven months, of some 240 people, 154 have to date expressed an interest in negotiating the transfer of their property. Within the confines of the Budget we are providing almost $10m this year to meet the costs of acquiring property. The actual acquisition of properties is a matter that is being dealt with by the Department of Local Government and Administrative Services under the ministry of my colleague the Minister for Local Government and Administrative Services (Mr Uren).

Another matter referred to by the honourable member for McPherson (Mr White) was the Sydney international terminal. That has been mentioned a number of times by speakers from the Opposition. Again, this Government is doing more than any other government in history to improve the aviation infrastructure, the development of services. I heard criticism about Darwin-again, a problem which honourable members opposite when in government could never face and which we inherited from them. I heard criticism about Sydney, a problem they could never handle, let alone the problem of the international terminal. These problems did not develop just in the last 31/2 years. They have been developing for over a decade.

I think the best way to handle these criticisms is to run through these problems and show what we as a government are doing to address them. Perth international terminal will be opened in a couple of weeks, on 25 October, by the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke). That represents $70m worth of investment by the taxpayer to provide a long-needed better service for people of Perth and visitors to Perth. The Sydney international terminal is a program for the expenditure of $20m. The position is not, as stated by the honourable member for Wide Bay (Mr Millar) and other Opposition speakers, that that program will not assist the situation. That program will provide an 80 per cent increase in the handling capacity of the international terminal. There will be a need for a second terminal. That matter will be referred to the Federal Airports Corporation as a priority project. But there is no way that that second terminal can be constructed and completed before the mid 1990s, and we cannot wait until then to deal with the problem. We are providing money in this Budget for the commencement of works on the international terminal at Sydney which, as I said, without going into the detail of them this morning, will provide for an 80 per cent increase in capacity.

Along with that increase in capacity will be a corresponding improvement in the quality of management services. It is not just a matter of the area of a building; it is the quality of the service provided. It is a matter of how the people are processed and how the airlines themselves handle people. I am coming very firmly to the conclusion that on the one hand airlines are very quick to call for increased expenditure, but much quicker still in blaming others, particularly if they are public servants, when they are not able to handle the processing of the passengers themselves. A principal problem at Sydney is the scheduling of aircraft, and on that question the airlines have been utterly inflexible. I propose to address that question. But no taxpayer, no government, can afford to keep on investing money in public transport facilities to cope with very short duration peaks. It is a matter of making better use of the facility and of better scheduling of aircraft into the facilities, be they train, bus or aircraft facilities such as in this case.

The Brisbane Airport program represents an expenditure by the Australian taxpayer of almost $400m. It was never envisaged and decided-even by the previous Government at the time-that there would be a new international terminal in the works that were then planned and initiated. That was planned for some time into the 1990s. Works were undertaken to expand the existing building. Further works will be carried out to assist in that position. But to suggest-I am disappointed that the honourable member for Wide Bay has done this-that the location of the existing international terminal in relation to the new airport will, when it opens in October next year, in some way cause hazards for the operation of aircraft is nonsense. All those matters were considered by the honourable member's Government when the decisions were made some years ago. Since then, to confirm the position further, there have been improvements in brake technology and tyre technology. The airlines do not make that comment. They are quite happy with the arrangements envisaged. After all, they are the operators of the aircraft. It is their aircraft and tyres that will be affected, not the Government's property. So in this case it is the industry that is satisfied with the arrangements.

In the case of Coolangatta, a new taxiway has been put in to improve its performance and adequacy and to get more aircraft in. In Canberra, a long overdue expansion of the terminal is proceeding. When we talk about tourism and people coming to this country to visit the national capital, we should realise that they all come through that totally inadequate building. At a very modest expenditure of $2.3m that building is being almost doubled in size. In Townsville, a new terminal is being built which will be completed by the end of next year. Under aerodrome local ownership plans, Casino Airport has been upgraded, as have the airports at Wagga, Broken Hill, Kangaroo Island, Tamworth, Bundaberg and Albury. All of those investments have been completed and better services are now available to the country people using those airports. The upgrading at Coffs Harbour is also under way. So considerable work is being done by this Government in respect of airport investment around this country. There has been a record level of expenditure. We are very aware of the contribution that new infra- structure makes and of the need for it to be carried forward and completed as quickly as possible.

The honourable member for McPherson raised a point about the Sydney international terminal which, I say again, is a legacy from his Government and his colleagues. It is utter hypocrisy for the honourable member for Fadden (Mr Jull) and the honourable member for McPherson to raise the issue of interlining. A regime of domestic aviation arrangements was inflicted upon this nation by the present Opposition when in government. But Opposition members now come to me and to this Government and say: `This is awful. How can you allow this to proceed?' I say to them: `I am sorry. It is your creation. You inflicted it upon this country. There is a need for change and that change will be undertaken in a consultative way'. A review of domestic aviation arrangements is under way by a committee chaired by Mr Tom May which is due to report to the Government later this year. After that has come in and we have had the benefit of all that consultation with and contributions from people, we will look at what type of new arrangement best meets the needs of the Australian people.

A decision on interlining was made in 1979 by the then Minister for Transport, Mr Nixon, without consultation with the industry; it was just imposed. In addition, since that period, there has been an expansion in the number of international gateways; so I suspect that the whole issue of interlining may not be of the same magnitude as it was when it was imposed upon the Australian people.

The honourable member for McPherson and other speakers raised the issue of private sector funding for Brisbane Airport. There has been no proposal for private sector funding of Brisbane Airport. The honourable member may have been referring to a tender that was lodged by a group in Queensland when tenders were invited for the construction of a hotel-motel complex at the airport. There were eight expressions of interest earlier in the year and then three tenders were received. Those tenders were examined and considered and legal advice was sought to ensure that any action that we took was properly within the law. We were given the best independent legal advice that two of the tenders could not be evaluated by the Department of Aviation as they were non-conforming tenders. As I have said, there is no proposal for private investment in Brisbane Airport.

Comments were made about Sydney and Darwin airports. We were told that Peter Stainlay from Qantas Airways Ltd had put forward a proposal involving $20m. That is stale news. That was a proposal of many months ago which was subsequently withdrawn by Qantas when Qantas realised that it had misunderstood the nature of the improvements to the Sydney international terminal. It had misunderstood that the improvements would provide an 80 per cent increase in passenger handling capacity and the proposal was withdrawn. I invited Qantas to look more closely at the proposal and it found that it would not have cost $20m; it would have cost more like $70m. Again, that information is totally inaccurate; there is no such proposal.

In the case of Darwin, a proposal was put forward but all it was was a proposal to lend the money to the Government and for the Government to pay it back with interest later. That did not address the real question of what is the best value for the money available in terms of a new terminal at Darwin. Certainly, no one disputes that the terminal at Darwin is inadequate. That situation did not develop in just the last 3 1/2 years. However, it is a matter of getting the best value for the taxpayer from the project and that is what we are doing. The issue of the travel agents convention also involves the very important issue of interlining. I have explained to the House how that matter is being addressed.

The honourable member for Fadden raised a matter concerning Japan-Australia fares. The honourable member for Fadden got it the wrong way round. The Australian fares have gone up to compensate for the drop in the value of the Australian dollar. It is proposed that the Japanese fares will go down to compensate for the hardening or appreciation in the value of the Japanese yen.

I remain mystified by the comments of the honourable member about other airlines when we have a major export industry, which our national carrier, Qantas, is. It is acknowledged across the world as being a major and successful international air transport operator. It does not have any price protection. The Department of Aviation has a virtually nil participation in fare setting which is left very much to the airlines. It has a share of capacity. I marvel at the capacity of Opposition members to knock Australia's own airline, which is successful in a fiercely competitive market and which makes a major contribution to tourism in this country. Qantas spends $100m a year abroad on Australian tourism, which is far more than any other organisation or government has spent. It provides thousands of jobs in this country, both directly and indirectly. At a time when we are asking people to buy Australian and we are talking about developing foreign exchange earnings for Australia, I look for support in the development of Australia's international air transport industry. Instead, we have the old time-worn `knock the Aussies' attitude from the Opposition which believes that people overseas can always do things better. I am sorry, but I reject that. If the industry were not competitive or efficient or if it had some high level of price protection, I could understand that type of attitude. But that is not the case.

The concluding remark I make is that, in whatever field of transport or aviation, this Government is doing more in the areas under its jurisdiction than any other government has done in a comparable period to improve infrastructure and services available, be they air, sea, rail or road. The Opposition has an awful problem. It is now 11.35 a.m. In the mornings the Opposition always calls for the spending of more money, be it on airports, roads, donations, subsidies or whatever. But come Question Time this afternoon members of the Opposition will have undergone a culture change. At 2 o'clock they will be asking questions about why this Government is not doing enough to reduce the deficit and why it has not made some really fair dinkum expenditure cuts. The honourable member for Cowper (Mr Nehl) said that the Budget is a Claytons Budget and that it is time that the Government really made some fair dinkum expenditure cuts and got down to a nil deficit. We do not see it that way. The Budget is a balanced Budget designed to promote the development of this economy and to provide improved and more efficient services.

DEBATE.TITLE: SOCIAL SECURITY AND VETERANS' AFFAIRS (MISCELLANEOUS AMENDMENTS) BILL 1986

PROCTEXT.PARA: Bill presented by Mr Howe, and read a first time.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Howe The Hon B.L.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the Bill be now read a second time.

This Bill contains amendments to social security and veterans' affairs legislation to implement decisions affecting those portfolios in the 1986-87 Budget. Honourable members will be aware that, as a result of international economic conditions, there have been significant reductions in Australia's national income. The Government believes that through the Budget and other policy changes, the problems which this creates can be faced squarely and remedial changes put into place quickly and decisively. These changes must be made so that our domestic economy and standard of living can be adjusted to our current circumstances. The Budget therefore incorporates very large reductions in spending, amongst other measures.

In making difficult decisions, the Government has sought to ensure that the burden of change is spread as fairly as possible across the community, while maintaining the Australian Labor Party's traditional commitment to the needy. Overall, there are reductions against forward estimates of some $500m in social security. This restraint was achieved with no discounting of indexed rises in pensions and benefits. Within a very constrained budgetary framework, we have been able to steer spending towards some areas of greatest need. And we have continued to tighten administrative procedures in ways that add to the integrity of our programs. Most important of all, nothing in this Budget jeopardises our continuing review and reform of the income security system.

Two major decisions included in the Bill which will affect the Social Security Act 1947 are as follows. Future six-monthly indexation increases to pensioners and beneficiaries will continue to be paid in full, but will be deferred for six weeks, that is, three pension pay-days, from November 1986; and the measures implemented last year to reduce `poverty traps' in the social security system will be delayed by eight months, until July 1987. The deferral of indexation increases is estimated to save $129.2m in 1986-87 and $111.4m in 1987-88, and the deferral of the `poverty traps' legislation is estimated to save $126.6m in 1986-87 and will cost $196.5m in 1987-88. These are the only changes to the general pension and benefits area. They do not represent major structural change, and involve minimal disadvantage for those in greatest need. In line with the Government's aim to target welfare payments to the most needy, family allowance for student children between 16 and 18 years of age will be income-tested. Families with household income-that is, combined husband and wife taxable incomes-over $39,000 will not be eligible for family allowance. Estimated savings from this measure are $20m in 1986-87 and $49m in 1987-88.

The Government has also decided to increase some payments in areas which will assist the most needy, particularly young families. Additional pension or benefit applicable for a dependent child of a pensioner or beneficiary will be increased by $1 to $17 per week, in November 1986; the rate of double orphan's pension will be increased by $4.30 to $60 per month, from November 1986; the rate of handicapped child's allowance will be increased by $7 to $92 per month, from November 1986; and the rate of mobility allowance will be increased by $1 to $11 per week, from November 1986. Estimated costs from these four measures are: Increase in additional pension or benefit by $1 per week-$28.3m in 1986-87 and $44.7m in 1987-88; increase in double orphan's pension by $4.30 per month-$0.2m in 1986-87 and $0.3m in 1987-88; increase in handicapped child's allowance by $7 per month-$1.7m in 1986-87 and $2.7m in 1987-88; and increase in mobility allowance by $1 per week-$0.4m in 1986-87 and $0.6m in 1987-88.

Other decisions reflected in the Bill which will further rationalise the social security system are as follows. The current arrangements by which sickness benefit is either reduced or recovered by reference to compensation payable to the beneficiary will be extended to invalid pension, unemployment benefit, rehabilitation allowance and sheltered employment allowance, as from May 1987. The level of rent payable for a person to be eligible for rent assistance will increase from $10 to $15 per week, as from December 1986. Dual eligibility for both a social security pension or benefit and a war or defence widow's pension will be restructured, from November 1986. Dual eligibility for both a social security pension or Commonwealth educational scheme payment will be removed, other than for current cases, from January 1987.

Estimated savings from these four measures are: Extension of the current arrangements concerning compensation payments $21m in 1986-87, and $50m in 1987-88, in conjunction with savings from the inclusion of the `apportionment formula' in the current sickness benefit arrangements from July 1986; increase in the rent threshold-$8.8m in 1986-87, and $16.1m in 1987-88; removal or reduction of dual eligibility for both a social security pension or benefit and a war or defence widow's pension-$4.1m in 1986-87, and $35.1m in 1987-88; and savings will occur in the Education portfolio as a result of the removal of dual eligibility for both a social security pension and an educational scheme payment.

The Government has announced a range of measures to tighten the administration of unemployment benefits and so ensure greater fairness in the allocation of limited funds. We are also introducing new arrangements which will improve the administration of widow's pension and supporting parent's benefit. These arrangements are designed both to assist these pensioners and beneficiaries and to ensure that the correct entitlement is paid.

In the area of unemployment benefit, the Bill will include amendments by which unemployment beneficiaries will have to be registered with the Commonwealth Employment Service to qualify for benefit, as from November 1986; beneficiaries will have to lodge their first income statements and applications for contribution of unemployment benefit in person, as from 1 November 1986; and arrangements will be made for beneficiaries aged over 55 years who have been receiving social security payments for a year to have relaxed reporting requirements. Estimated savings from these measures, and other measures not requiring legislation, are $33.9m in 1986-87 and $133.4m in 1987-88.

In addition to these measures, youth income proposals announced in the 1985-86 Budget are included in the Bill. The Bill will also amend the definition of `income' which applies in the pension and benefit income tests. The amendment will make it clear that the income test does not create an artificial distinction between capital and income. This development would be inconsistent with the long-standing philosophical approach to the scope of the income test, and would have substantial cost implications, apart from unduly distorting the flow of funds into particular types of investments. The amendment is designed to maintain the current approach to the income test, which will be administered in the same way as it has been in the past. Finally, within the social security area, the Bill will amend the assets test in a number of respects to correct deficiencies found after review. These changes are, as a package, revenue-neutral.

This Bill will also make some minor amendments to the Compensation (Commonwealth Government Employees) Act 1971 and the Seamen's Compensation Act 1911. The amendments will prevent the application of those Acts to employees of the Northern Territory Government and its statutory authorities, and to seamen working in the territorial waters of the Territory. These persons will, from the commencement of the amendments, be covered by a proposed Work Health Act of the Northern Territory. There are small savings from this change in arrangements. I say in passing that a review is being conducted of the Compensation (Commonwealth Government Employees) Act and its administration. I hope that that review will be completed in the current session of Parliament and that legislation will follow. I make this comment because yesterday the Australian called for a review of the agreement with the United Kingdom. I made that announcement when the House discussed the Social Security (Proportional Portability of Pensions) Amendment Bill, and those negotiations have commenced. I make that comment because, apparently, sometimes these announcements are not heard.

This Bill will also make a number of amendments to the Veterans' Entitlements Act 1986 to give effect to the Government's decisions announced in the Budget. The opportunity is also taken in this Bill to make a number of machinery amendments, the need for which has become apparent from the experience of the last four months since the Veterans' Entitlements Act came into operation.

The Bill will, in unison with amendments to the Social Security Act 1947, defer for three pension pay-days the payment of increased rates of pensions and allowances which are subject to indexation in accordance with movements in the consumer price index. Indexation of income and property value limits for the purpose of the income and assets test will also be deferred. This proposal will lead to savings of $26.6 million in 1986-87 and $23.3 million in 1987-88.

The Bill will also provide that the rate of service pension payable to a widow who is also in receipt of a war widow's pension, currently payable at $228.20 per fortnight, will be frozen at the rate payable on 1 November 1986. Where service pension is granted to such a war widow at a later date the maximum rate of pension payable will be $120.10 per fortnight.

The other main proposal relates to an option to recover from health benefits funds that amount of fund benefit that would have been payable to their contributors who are treated without charge at the expense of the Repatriation Commission. It is emphasised that this arrangement is entirely voluntary on the part of entitled beneficiaries. This proposal would save an estimated $7.2m in 1986-87 and an estimated $10m in 1987-88.

Other amendments of a budgetary nature include increases in the rates of certain allowances and pensions. The rates of pensions payable to orphans of deceased veterans are to be increased; the rate of additional pensions payable to veterans suffering from certain incapacities will be increased, as will the rates of attendant allowance and the rates of clothing allowance. Other amendments are to align the assets and income test provisions with those proposed to be made to the Social Security Act 1947. Similar amendments are also made to the Seamen's War Pensions and Allowances Act 1940 where appropriate.

Finally, the Bill will include savings provisions to ensure that rights to seek reviews of certain decisions by the Administrative Appeals Tribunal are preserved and transitional provisions to ensure that money due to the pensioner but unpaid at the death of a pensioner before the commencement of the Veterans' Entitlement Act 1986 may be disbursed under that Act. I commend the Bill to the House and table the explanatory memorandum.
