TALK.START.PARA: —I wish to make a few remarks about the expenditure of the Department of Social Security first and then mention briefly that of the Department of Community Services. Despite the general community perception as a result of the Budget, expenditure within the Department of Social Security has increased, not decreased. The post-Budget publicity suggested that overall expenditure had declined by some $500m. This is not the case. Total expenditure by the Department increased by $1.1 billion in round terms. Many people in the community, including the welfare lobby itself, believe that we are spending more than we ever have in the past and we are doing less good with it.

SPEECH.PARA: An examination of this Government's expenditure priorities, as revealed in the Budget Papers and in the papers circulated by the Minister subsequent to the Budget, indicate its rather mean and miserly approach to aged members of our community. As I said, total expenditure within the Department has increased by about $1.1 billion. It is interesting to note that the only sections of benefits in which expenditure declined in absolute terms were total payments for family allowances and payments for what is known as a double orphan's pension. The decline in family allowances is about 11.2 per cent by my calculations.

It is also interesting to note-I have been told this unofficially by certain people within the Department-that many of the estimates for the increased expenditure for certain categories of benefits are dubious and based on assumptions which some people within the Department and others outside believe will not be fulfilled. I am quite sceptical about the estimates for the cost of unemployment benefits in the coming year. The total expenditure anticipated in that area is for an increase of 13.9 per cent. The Treasurer (Mr Keating) told us that that did not include an allowance for some 10,000 people who are currently receiving unemployment benefits but who are not entitled to them. I was quite heartened to see that the Treasurer, if not the Minister for Social Security (Mr Howe), is prepared to admit that some people are currently receiving benefits when they do not deserve them and that that has been taken into account when calculating the estimate in the coming year.

This Budget reflects the Government's failure to address effectively policy problems within the Department of Social Security. Total expenditure has increased for just about every benefit area. Areas of particular interest include that of benefits for supporting parents. The estimate for the increase in that area is 9.9 per cent, taking the total expenditure to the order of $1.4 billion. Only this week in this place we had tabled a discussion paper for changes in child support procedures within Australia. There is bipartisan support for review and reform of this area and for many years there has been considerable community pressure for action. The Opposition moved a private member's Bill in the Senate last year suggesting changes to the family law and its administration and I remind the Minister that this Government has been in power since March 1983. Last week it tabled a discussion paper which was a product of work prepared by a consultant who was appointed in January 1986. The Government was elected in March 1983; it appointed a consultant in January 1986; it tabled a paper this month. Quite frankly, that is not a record of high priority or determination of action to achieve reform and change in this very important area, which is a growing area of expenditure in welfare.

There are certain concerns in the community about the effectiveness of welfare payments-the effectiveness of payments which in many cases do not represent an effective utilisation of taxpayers' funds. I believe that the failure of the Government to do anything about changes in child support is an indication of its preparedness to let the system roll on, notwithstanding the cost to the taxpayer. It is also interesting to note where the Government is prepared to save money. This Government has decided that the aged section of our community is perhaps the easiest to crack down on. The Government can implement its penny pinching programs, trim a few million dollars here and a hundred million dollars there by making life a little tougher and harder for those people who have retired from the work force and who no longer have the capacity to fight back in the way that other sections of the community can fight. It began when the Government first came to office and introduced the assets test. The first version of the assets test was an absolute disaster. It was like the present fringe benefits tax and the same Prime Minister initiated the review. I believe that we have had four or five versions of the assets test and we are now coming up for the sixth-

TALK.START.PARA: —And it is still a disaster.

—Of course it is still a disaster and it will always be a disaster because the philosophy underlying the assets test is wrong, in conjunction with our current welfare system and our retirement incomes policy-
—What a pathetic excuse.

—The left wing of the Labor Party knows exactly what the problem is and so does the Minister. The Australian Labor Party will be lucky to get 30 per cent of the total vote throughout Australia as a result, notwithstanding the Government's decision to spend a couple of million dollars of the taxpayers' money promoting the fringe benefits tax and running another massive advertising campaign. TALK.START.PARA: —It will be abolished.

I wish to make some remarks about other things that this Government has done in an attempt to prune a few million dollars off the aged members of our community. SPEECH.PARA: The worst thing that the Government has done is to defer the poverty trap relief measures. Those measures were introduced in October 1985 and had bipartisan support. TALK.START.PARA: —The shadow Minister for Social Security, the honourable member for Richmond (Mr Blunt) is a unique individual. His contributions in this place never cease to amaze me. It also sharply reduced subsistence allowance for veterans in relation to meals and accommodation when they are referred for medical treatment. SPEECH.PARA: They are just some of the measures arising from that mini-Budget of 1985 which was a precursor to a program of cutbacks on veterans who served their country in time of war. Then the Veterans' Entitlements Bill came along. After a prolonged period of negotiation and determined effort by the coalition and others we secured a large number of amendments. In particular the draconian 40-year rule was removed from that legislation. Notwithstanding that, we had this sharp contraction in the criteria for totally and permanently incapacitated veterans, especially those who had retired. I have sought and obtained through Senate Estimates Committee F a good deal of detailed information in relation to the particular estimates and savings assessed which are involved in this area. I would commend to people who are interested in this subject the Hansard of Senate Estimates Committee F, and suggest that they can read that in conjunction with these remarks. Provision was also made for termination of the dependant's allowance by commutation, albeit on a voluntary basis; no further increases were to be provided for in the dependant's allowance.

Then we have the Budget and the Estimates before the Committee at the moment. What do we see? We see another range of cutbacks. War widows and their dependants, as well as service pensioners with their fringe benefits, will no longer have access to the repatriation pharmaceutical benefits scheme. Let me be accurate by saying that they will still have access to the national health scheme. War widows who also receive an age pension will have the social security component frozen at a maximum level of $60.05. An additional Budget decision to apply a reducing permanent maximum level below the $60.05 has now been dropped, following a very successful campaign by veterans' organisations and the War Widows Guild, involving many people at various levels, including two people who are present in the chamber at this time. I am delighted with that breakthrough and my campaigning and indeed that of the honourable member for Dobell (Mr Lee) and others who took a particular interest in this issue.

We have also had the cutback which is involved with the deferment of consumer price index related increases for veterans' pensions. It is ironical that, as luck would have it, the Social Security and Veterans' Affairs (Miscellaneous Amendments) Bill, which the Minister for Social Security (Mr Howe) introduced a short while ago, set out the various amounts involved. I had extracted them from the Estimates paper to put them into this contribution, but there really is no need because they were all detailed a few minutes ago in the second reading speech of the Minister.

We have had this range of cutbacks relating to veterans and particularly relating to war widows. We have had an additional cutback embraced by the decision of the Government that affects veterans who, through incentive, through voluntary determination, have taken out private health insurance. The Government is welshing on its obligation to pick up the treatment costs for those eligible veterans. It will go to the Hospitals Contribution Fund of Australia Ltd, the Medical Benefits Fund of Australia Ltd and other private health insurance funds in a most discriminatory way and require them to pay the costs involved with that hospitalisation. That represents an estimate-it is a Government estimate-of a $7m transfer in added burden to the private health insurance funds of this nation. It will in turn add to the overall cost for all Australians because the Government is not honouring its full obligations in respect of veterans. This is embraced in the estimates now before the House.

There have been other cutbacks-above all, the continuing cutback of the assets test, which has seen over 13,000 veterans have their service pensions reduced or cancelled. The honourable member for Gippsland (Mr McGauran), who is in the chamber, will be aware-he follows these matters closely-that the assets test has impacted more heavily on Victoria than any other State. It has a tendency to impact more heavily on veterans than general age pensioners.

I am speaking of a range of cutbacks that have been carried out at the initiation of this Government over the past 18 months. It ill becomes the Government to accuse the coalition of proposing a series of policy changes that bear on the continued existence or otherwise of the Veterans' Affairs portfolio. After all, the coalition created the modern Department of Veterans' Affairs. In any event, following the extraordinary breakfast at the Lodge yesterday-the bash outer Ministers breakfast; the bomb breakfast-we know that junior Ministers, including the Minister for Veterans' Affairs, might be on the short end and might be rolled over by Senator Richardson. In any event, the portfolio might be restructured. I seek an assurance here and now that for the balance of this Parliament there will not be the restructuring that is suggested in respect of the Veterans' Affairs portfolio following the breakfast yesterday at the Lodge, which was clearly a case of shuffling deck chairs on the Titanic. We know that Senator Richardson will end up being the next shadow Minister for Veterans' Affairs, in the same way that the honourable member for Charlton (Mr Robert Brown) will end up being the next shadow Treasurer. This will happen only if the honourable members are able to retain their seats following the big swing that will take place at the next Federal election.

The Department of Veterans' Affairs estimates before the Committee provide an increase in overall Veterans' Affairs expenditure from $3.5 billion to $3.8 billion. That is the figure that the Minister likes to latch on to but it camouflages the reality in terms of a number of programs, including those involving war widows and the veterans that I have mentioned in other categories. Those programs will be subject to cutbacks as a result of Budget and off-Budget moves which the Government has initiated in its general approach to those who served their country in time of war.

The Australian War Memorial has been the subject of some controversy. The Budget review of the Department of Veterans' Affairs contained a generous reference to the War Memorial and many of the other Budget changes. It completely fails, however, to make any reference to the freezing of the social security component of the war widows' package where there is also an eligibility for an age pension. I realise that this has something to do with the fact that some of the matters relate to the Social Security portfolio rather than the Veterans' Affairs portfolio, but it is something which war widows would have liked to read about in the publication. As I have said, there is no reference to it in this veterans' affairs budgetary publication. Further details have emerged in the Bill that the Minister for Social Security introduced earlier today.

The coalition will fight tooth and nail to ensure the retention of the independence of the Australian War Memorial and the operation of its management council. We shall not allow the Government or the Minister to use whatever may be the outcome of the current independent investigation as a vehicle or tool to sabotage the independence of the War Memorial or to move down the path of making it some form of special peace museum, or in any other way detracting from the fundamental traditional, historic, significant and vital role of this great institution.

In the controversy leading up to the appointment of the independent investigation it has emerged that Parliament might have been misled by an answer to a question which I lodged about the reconstruction of a staircase at great expense-a six figure amount-at the War Memorial due to some error between the War Memorial and the National Capital Development Commission. Can the Minister clarify what might have been the correct answer to that question on notice which was answered by the Minister for Veterans' Affairs through his representative in this House? I would appreciate clarification. It has been suggested that the Minister's answer that was given a few months ago was incorrect. I understand from publicity that this matter is the subject of part of the independent investigation that is now proceeding.

TALK.START.PARA: —In 1988, which is really only a short time away, we shall be celebrating our Bicentenary. What does that really mean? Does it mean a lot of flag waving and the construction of monuments all over Australia, or will it signal the first real Aussie assault in 200 years on the discrimination against poor people in favour of the rich? Australia started out 200 years ago with essentially two classes-those who came here with authority, gold braid and guns, and those who came here in chains. Standards and styles have changed and the standard of living of the poor has increased over the past 200 years, but in relative terms there is not that much difference.

SPEECH.PARA: Out of a population of 16 million or 17 million people, two million to three million are living in poverty. The actual number depends on the definition of poverty, but when we get down to that level it does not really matter what definition is used because those concerned are in poverty. They do not have enough food. The number includes 800,000 young children, the children of Australia who are our future. Let us put this into some sort of perspective. The distance from Sydney to Perth is about 3,000 kilometres. If those who now live in poverty were to join hands they could stretch across the width of the continent. If the two million to three million poorest people in this country linked hands, they could stretch across 3,000 kilometres of this continent. That is what this Government, the people of Australia and the Opposition have to address.

Let us consider the distribution of wealth in this country. The top one per cent of adult individuals own about $125,000m; the top 5 per cent about $250 billion; and the top 10 per cent about $300 billion. This means that the top one per cent have about $1.5m each. The same studies have shown that the poorest 2.5 million people have as much wealth as the richest 200,000 and that the bottom 50 per cent of Australians now have only 8 per cent of the country's wealth. That is what poverty and the maldistribution of wealth is all about in this country.

Poverty means feeding kids on 70c a meal. How many honourable members would like to feed their kids on 70c a meal? How many people outside the House would like to do that? No one would like to feed his kids on 70c a meal, but that is what two million to three million people have to do every day. Poverty means sending kids to school without breakfast in the hope that someone will give them something to eat at school. It means being behind with the rent and wondering whether one will be thrown out of one's house. It means begging for handouts at the local court or having nowhere to sleep at night. Shadow Ministers tell us constantly how bad this all is and how sad it is. They tell us how heartless this Government is. We shall hear more and more of that as the debate continues. What a load of rubbish! What a lot of crocodile tears! Opposition members berate the Government but they will leave the House at the end of the debate, and in the streets and at meetings they will attack the unemployed, supporting mothers, the children of the poor and social security expenditure. It is no use Opposition members saying how bad everything is and how sad it is and then leaving this place and putting across the opposite message.

Even that behaviour would not be so bad if it were not for the fact that the economy and the country have suffered under their incompetence, negligence and deliberate policies that have caused structural poverty and the degradation of our industries. They protect and encourage now, as in the past, the people who are making money out of tax evasion. They have degraded the tax morality of this country. That is something against which we are fighting, and we shall continue to do so. Members of the Opposition will come into the chamber in a couple of hours for Question Time. They will bring up the fringe benefits tax again and they will again try to protect the wealthy of this country.

I shall not pretend that everything in the Budget is right, and neither will many Labor members. The honourable member for Melbourne (Mr Hand) said that quite capably in his address. The fact is that in very severe economic circumstances-very few of which were created by the Government; most of which were created by the long term policies of the Opposition-the Government has brought down what it could in terms of assisting those least able to assist themselves, those who have the least opportunity to develop themselves, to achieve, and to gain some security. Some people see social security as a safety valve-`They should be given just enough money to keep the rebellion down. Give them just enough unemployment benefit to stop them rising up in the streets'-as has occurred in Britain. I can assure honourable members that that is not the philosophy of the Minister for Social Security (Mr Howe). His commitment is far greater than that, and it always will be.

There needs to be a balance to ensure proper and efficient use of social security funds. The Minister and the Government have again dedicated themselves to ensuring that social security expenditure is not wasted. There are plenty of examples in the Budget. We have talked about them. To be quite frank, honourable members opposite have also agreed with most of those measures, which is a good thing. I shall not go into the initiatives that have been taken in the Budget because that has been done on many occasions and will be done in a later debate.

Because of the magnitude of poverty in this country, it takes billions of dollars to give a few cents here and a few dollars there. It is band-aid assistance. We must address the magnitude of poverty. I remind honourable members of what living in abject poverty means, and what it does to the living standards of all Australians. Australia is a very wealthy country. We might seem to have a balance of payments problem, and so on, at the moment, but we are a very wealthy country with tremendous potential. Our potential is limited only by our own lack of vision. It is limited by the fact that one in five Australians lives in poverty. It is limited by the economic rationalists of this country, the media commentators and the politicians who only look at next year's balance sheet. It is the quick buck, the quick fix, that restricts this country's vision. It restricts this country's ability to get back on its feet and to set structural change that will take it into the twenty-first century.

There are people in this country, many supported by honourable members opposite, who will not put their money where their country is. Last year, $7,000m of workers' money went out of this country into overseas economies. It is no wonder that we cannot get business going and achieve capital gain in this country when we send our own money overseas to build up the economies of other countries and then expect our country to develop some economic and industrial strength. If we are to reduce the social security budget and eradicate poverty, we need some long vision planning and application.

We have already seen the massive effects of unemployment. We will see them for a long time in an economic and social sense. Many people aged 25 to 30 years have not been able to work for a full month or a full year in their life because of structural unemployment. That is very expensive for this country and it will continue to be so. Who is paying for it? It is not the wealthy. Unfortunately, the Government has not imposed any real restrictions on the wealthy in this country. If we read the Business Review Weekly, we can see the wealth that has escalated in the past couple of years. It is the middle income earner, the pay as you earn taxpayer and the small business person who pay for it all. The big boys are getting the gravy without paying the bill. TALK.START.PARA: —My contribution to the debate will be centred mainly around health and social welfare aspects of the four departments that we are considering. A few days ago, the Medicare Levy Bill, which I prefer to call the Medicare tax, was passed by this chamber. That tax was increased from one per cent to 1.25 per cent-a 25 per cent increase. I am very pleased that the Minister for Health (Dr Blewett) is in the chamber. One of the most significant aspects of the Medicare legislation is the fact that there is an increase in the tax but a diminution of the services provided under Medicare. The maximum payable for each medical service will rise to a $20 contribution by the patient. Previously, the maximum service contribution by the patient was $10.

SPEECH.PARA: We have seen the abolition of the private hospital bed day subsidy, which will save the Government about $140m. It means that private health insurance funds' contributions have risen in all States, and not in a moderate way, as was stated by the Minister for Health in his second reading speech. We have a diminution of services in that elective surgery queues in this country get longer and longer. If the Minister for Health doubts that point, he should go to some of the large hospitals in his own State of South Australia or those in New South Wales or Victoria, talk to some of the specialists there and find out how many people are on the elective surgery waiting list. It is a disgrace when one considers that the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) said repeatedly, both before and after coming to office in 1983, that there would be a hospital bed available for all Australians.

Trust is a very important aspect of politics. I suggest that with the broken promises we have seen by both the Prime Minister and the Minister for Health, they cannot be trusted on the provision of health services. What nonsense it was to make a statement that a bed would be available for all Australians when, 3 1/2 years further down the track, we find that the queues for elective surgery are lengthening. Most people wait in vain. Only acute conditions will be treated. If the Minister doubts that, he should talk to some of the arthritis sufferers-people with twisted hands and fingers, people who want fairly simple operations to relieve them of their discomfort and pain. Those people, especially the elderly, are unable to have those operations. Major operations, such as hip replacements, are also affected. I predict that that diminution of services will continue. The Hawke socialist Government has proved that it is big on promises but small on delivery.

I turn to the actual level of the Medicare tax. The Prime Minister stated 18 months ago that there would be no increase in the level of the Medicare tax, and the Health Minister made the same claim. Yet, just 18 months later, there is a 25 per cent increase in the tax. We must remember that that clear and unequivocal election promise was made after Labor had been in government for 20 months. There could be no suggestion of shifting the blame on to the previous Government. We remember the old line that Labor used-that the economy was much worse when it assumed office than it thought it was, and it had to do this or that; therefore, it had an excuse for breaking a promise. There is no excuse for breaking this promise. The Prime Minister knows that and the Health Minister knows that. It is like the Prime Minister's promise on the capital gains tax. All of us recall that. In his policy speech in 1984 Mr Hawke said: `There will be no capital gains tax. All of our critics in the Opposition know clearly that there will be no capital gains tax'. This was a clear case of the misleading and the deception of the Australian people. It is no wonder that Mr 75 per cent is now Mr 45 per cent. The people do not like to be duped, and duped they have been by Prime Minister Hawke.

Let me turn to the Health Minister. As I said earlier, I am pleased he is in the chamber. Like the Prime Minister, the Health Minister barnstormed around this country pre-election and post-election piously and proudly claiming that there would be no increase in the Medicare levy. He is on the record prior to 1983; he is on the record following 1983; and he is on the record in September 1983 after the introduction of the Medicare legislation as saying that there would be no increase in the Medicare levy. What a joke. What a laugh.

Obviously the Minister knows nothing about economics because even a grade 8 school child could tell at a glance that, with the encouragement of bulk billing, the overuse of medical services, the absence of an indentifiable cost-which has come about because the Minister has encouraged bulk billing-steady and rising inflation, wage indexation increasing all costs and spiralling hospital costs, the difference between what has been collected by the one per cent Medicare tax and the outgoings will increase enormously. This is exactly what has happened. The grade 8 school child could understand the trend and the mathematics but the Health Minister could not. Could he see it but, like the Prime Minister, was about deception? After the introduction of the Medicare legislation in 1983 he made the claim that the one per cent levy would do the job. I will quote from the Australian of 14 April 1983. He was in government as Health Minister then. He stated:
My department has checked the (Medicare) program and has confirmed we can deliver within 1 per cent . . .

One of two things applies to the Minister as far as I am concerned: Either he lacks grey matter or he has set about misleading and deceiving the Australian people. Whichever it is, he should be sacked. Two months ago, Dr Blewett, along with the Prime Minister, broke the promise not to increase the Medicare tax. Why? It was because Consolidated Revenue could no longer stand the strain. That is rather obvious. Health services costs blew out and it caught up with Prime Minister Hawke and Minister Blewett. They could not even work out what the average grade 8 school child could, so they had to do something about their desperation with escalating health costs. The result was the broken election promises of 18 months ago. Can honourable members hear Prime Minister Hawke saying to Health Minister Blewett, `Well, Neal, we knew we couldn't keep this promise when we made it. I would have liked to have stalled the increase a little longer, but too bad, the increase really has to take place now'?

Let me turn to the phoney tax cuts that we are going to have in December. I say `phoney tax cuts' because the taxes that have been introduced by this Government over the past two or three years make the so-called tax cuts that we are to receive in December just that-phoney. At the moment we are in a mess with the fringe benefits tax. Do honourable members recall the promise made by the Prime Minister that no capital gains tax would be introduced? There have been regular increases in the excise on alcohol, cigarettes, tobacco products and petrol and oils. There are new taxes on milk flavoured products and fruit juices and increases in the wine tax. There has been a saving of revenue with the introduction of the assets test. The Medicare tax has increased by 25 per cent to 1.25 per cent. This big taxing Government is offering tax cuts in December.

TALK.START.PARA: —And July.

—They will not be any better in July than they are in December because they are phoney to start with. They are phoney in December and they will be phoney in July. Veterans and their dependants and war widows have had benefits withdrawn or reduced. Is it any wonder that members of the Australian public are becoming more disenchanted and disillusioned with the Hawke socialist Government? The Hawke Government ought to be thrown out lock, stock and barrel.

TALK.START.PARA: —I am indebted to the honourable member for Phillip for her question. Let me make it clear that under the Hawke Labor Government there will be no mining of any sort in the areas comprising former stages 1 and 2 of Kakadu National Park. Kakadu National Park is one of Australia's great environmental treasures. Indeed, it is one of the world's great environmental treasures, as is evidenced by the fact that it is one of some 200 areas on the World Heritage List. It is one of the most beautiful wetlands in the world, a sanctuary for more than 200 species of bird life. It contains the finest collection of Aboriginal rock art in the world. It has a sensitive landscape and unique geological features that make it an area that must be carefully managed and preserved.

ANSWER.PARA: The reports of Geopeko Mineral Exploration's exploration in Kakadu have been drawn to my attention. I have been advised that, under the national park legislation, pre-existing mineral interests are preserved. Geopeko, therefore, is entitled under law to explore in the areas of its existing leases-to explore. If, as media reports indicate, Geopeko is exploring outside pre-existing mineral leases, the Government will seek to prevent that activity through the courts. As Peko has been advised on previous occasions, the Government does not accept that the mere application for a leasehold interest carries in itself any right to explore or mine. As far as Peko's existing leases are concerned, while the Government cannot prevent further exploration occurring, we will take every step within our power to ensure that no mining of any kind takes place within the existing Kakadu National Park.

I am advised that Peko-Wallsend Operations Ltd has 14 mineral leases in the stage 2 area, totalling around 550 acres but in five separate areas. My information is that these leases, small and scattered as they are, do not provide a sufficient area to establish a mine, and we will not grant additional leases. ANSWER.PARA: We all recognise-certainly it is recognised within the Australian Council of Social Service-that this country faces difficult economic circumstances and that this represents a period of restraint. It has been argued by those on the opposite side of this House, both in response to the Government's Budget and on other countless occasions, that there ought to be further cuts in expenditure and that those cuts would have to include social welfare expenditure. We have been prepared to exercise that restraint and to make very tough decisions. Let me say that they were tough and people were well aware of the consequences of those decisions.

There is another side to that. If we are to call for restraint and say that there need to be expenditure cuts affecting people, some of whom are the poorest in the Australian community, the other side of that is that we have to have a fair taxation system in this country. Whatever one may say about every detail of the fringe benefits tax, we are no longer arguing about the details; we are arguing about the fundamental principles of taxation and a fair taxation system. It seems to me and to people within the welfare sector incongruous that those people who call the loudest for restraint and most strongly for cuts in social welfare expenditure have not been prepared to accept any initiative designed to restore some equity to the Australian taxation system.

Let us look at Opposition statements. When it comes to the elimination of fraud, the Opposition is opposed to an identity card. The Opposition is opposed to the issue of a tax on capital when almost every other country of the Organisation for Economic Co-operation and Development, including the United States of America, has some form of such a tax. When it comes to a modest fringe benefits tax that aims to prevent people from seeking to avoid payment of sometimes very large amounts of money-that is, to avoid simply paying what they owe in tax-the Opposition is the first to jump in and seek political advantage in terms of its attack. The reality is that we have to accept an example cited by the Prime Minister the other day-the case of someone who was avoiding effectively $35,000 in tax. This Parliament is not always about opportunism; it is not always about cheap point scoring. The intended consequence of the policy of the Opposition is that that privileged wealthy minority should not pay any contribution to the rev- enue. We have recently seen an indication of the 200 wealthiest Australians. It is only as a result of the operation of a capital gains tax on a large proportion of the income generated by those people that some contribution will be made to the general revenue. It is the intended consequences of the Opposition's position that those people should remain untaxed; that they should pay no contribution to the general revenue. That is the intended consequence of its policy.

ANSWER.PARA: Let me say that the intended consequence of the capital gains tax policy of the Hawke Government is that there shall be an equitable contribution to the general revenue in this country from people who, up until this point, have escaped making their fair contribution because they had friends in the Opposition who regard it as fair that one should increase the tax burden on the ordinary honest average taxpayers in this country by allowing the privileged few to escape their burden. Our intended consequence is to bring an end to that inequity that has plagued this country for too long.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Prime Minister. Do recent favourable developments involving important economic indicators such as employment growth, the value of the Australian dollar, interest rates and money supply growth, provide any evidence that the Government's policies to address Australia's new economic circumstances are proving to be effective?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Hawke The Hon R.J.L.

TALK.START.PARA: —I suppose that the best evidence I could put to the honourable member that the Government's policies are working is that, since the Parliament resumed last week, we have not had one question-not one question-from the Opposition. If there were evidence that the Government's policies were not working, it is just possible that we would have had a question from the Opposition. I guess that that is the best test. But there is increasing evidence, not only that the Government's policies are right but also that they are beginning to produce the needed responses within the Australian economy.

ANSWER.PARA: It is particularly heartening, at least for the overwhelming majority of Australians but not for the Opposition, to see firming evidence that more and more companies in our manufacturing and service industries are taking advantage of Australia's substantially increased competitiveness. For example, the Australian Chamber of Manufactures pulse survey for the three months to August showed an increasing number of manufacturers finding overseas markets for their products, and also opportunities for import replacement. Mr Brian Powell, a name that is reasonably well known in this country, who is the Chief Executive of the Australian Chamber of Manufactures, was asked on the AM program of 15 September:
In what Australian industries are the export potentials over the next few months?
Mr Powell's response was:
Well, I think it would surprise you. I think it's occurring all over the place. It's in many areas not just the traditional ones. I think the only thing I'd exclude is bread.
The New South Wales Chamber of Manufactures-State Bank Survey also reported:
The competitive effects of the depreciation are beginning to occur.

For the December quarter a net balance of respondents expect a fall in import competition, and the net balance expecting an increase in export orders is the largest since the survey began in March 1985. That is not to deny that the current account deficit will remain high for some time yet, especially over the next few months when it will remain high for a number of reasons, including seasonal factors, the lagged effects of past depreciation and also the concentration of imports of aircraft. I would also point out that the most recent depreciation in June-July of about 10 per cent, coupled with some seasonal influences, will also tend to keep the consumer price index relatively high for about the next two quarters. But that will be tem- porary and, with the continued sensible policy on wages outcomes that will flow from the Government's policy, inflation will be trending down in 1987.

Let us make no mistake that Australia, for the reasons I have given, is responding to the challenges of current economic circumstances. It will be a long haul that we as a country have to engage in, but the correct policies are in place and are manifestly working. I suggest that growing recognition of that fact is one factor behind the improved tone of foreign exchange and money markets in recent weeks. This is particularly reflected in the 2 per cent fall in the key 90-day bill rate and one per cent in long term bond yield since the recent peak. If one looks at the statistical evidence, the surveys that are taken, the indications in the manufacturing and services sectors, the firming up in the exchange and money markets, every piece of evidence shows that the policies of this Government, correctly applied to the problems imposed upon us from outside, are working. This is in distinction to those of Opposition members, who wish that the adverse signs will continue since they have a vested interest in depression and recession. That is what they want, but Australian manufacturing industry, employers and workers are responding to the challenge and they will be successful.

TALK.START.PARA: —I refer the Acting Treasurer to the calls from the Government for businesses to invest to expand our productive capacity. Is the Minister aware that his Government's capital gains tax contains extremely limited roll-over relief for the disposal of business assets? Is the Minister further aware that if a business must sell a factory, warehouse or workshop to buy larger business premises to expand its operations and create employment, the business is liable to capital gains tax on the old premises, which will be a disincentive to the expansion of business-at a time when Australia desperately needs business investment? In view of the answer to the question asked by the honourable member for Wakefield, will this anomaly be considered by the Government when it reconsiders the effects of its disastrous capital gains tax? Is the matter raised in my question another intended or unintended consequence of Labor's capital gains tax?

—In March the Treasurer announced the principles guiding business reorganisation for which roll-overs-that is, deferral of capital gains tax liability-would be provided. This applies where no change occurs in the underlying ownership of the asset concerned or where the underlying asset, against which the taxpayer has a claim, does not change. The capital gains tax legislation lists specific cases of business reorganisation consistent with the principles that the Treasurer outlined in that statement last March on the provision of roll-overs. These include, for example, the transfer of assets between companies with 100 per cent common ownership. The Government has received representations suggesting that specific business reorganisations are consistent with the principles that the Treasurer outlined in March, but do not fit within any of the particular cases listed in that legislation. The Government is prepared to consider such possible additions to the existing list. This is nothing new. No-one who is at all objective would take any notice of the hollow laughter coming from the benches opposite. Amendments are made continuously to taxation legislation and we are quite happy to admit that the design of such legislation is not always perfect. The Treasurer has made it quite clear that he will look at the roll-over provisions and for this purpose he is at present considering such matters as the one raised by the honourable member for Fisher.

—Has the Acting Treasurer noted a report that the Government will conduct an advertising program concerning the fringe benefits tax? Will he inform the House whether there is any truth in that report?

—Yes, I have noted a report in today's media. Some consideration has been given by me and others in the Treasurer's private office to a campaign to inform the people of Australia about the new tax. —The Minister for Employment and Industrial Relations will have seen reports of the initial trade union proposal to change our wage fixing system, including a proposal to allow wage fixing bargains to take place at a company level. Does the Minister recall the numerous occasions during the past six months, including the most recent in this House on 23 September, when he said that such a proposal was not only `utterly irresponsible,' but also `unconstitutional' and `constitutionally unworkable'?
—Ooh!

—Will the Prime Minister please stop groaning. Some of his Ministers are having terrible trouble answering questions. Will the Minister send a copy of this advice to the unions and warn them that they are embarking on a proposal that is unconstitutional? Does he now concede that the only way to get reform and flexibility into our wage fixing process is to allow employers and their employees to make their own agreements on wages, conditions of employment and the removal of restrictive work practices?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Willis The Hon R.

TALK.START.PARA: —If the Deputy Leader of the Opposition really thinks that the Australian Council of Trade Unions is about to adopt the Opposition's wages policy, I assure him he is greatly mistaken. The proposals the Opposition has put up are impractical and unwise in many respects, and one of the defects is unconstitutionality. What is being looked at by the Government, the Australian Council of Trade Unions and employer organisations has nothing to do with the detailed proposals of the Opposition, but rather is concerned with obtaining a system which will provide us with an appropriate wages outcome in 1987-an outcome which is appropriate for the economic circumstances of our time.

ANSWER.PARA: For some time the Government has been examining the means by which we might adjust the wage fixing system. Our reason for doing so is that, first, we have in place a wage indexation system which, for economic reasons, can produce only partial wage indexation and therefore frustrates the prima facie supposition of full indexation. It is difficult to continue such an outcome indefinitely. Secondly, scope for increasing flexibility in the system is very limited in the current situation of low economic growth and partial indexation. For those reasons, the Government has been looking at a system which would be more appropriate in the circumstances that we now face, and that system would embrace a two-tier approach. It would provide for a general wage increase and a second tier of increases. In the current wage fixing system there is already a very limited second tier and our proposal would involve some expansion of that tier. Among the means by which increases could be obtained in the second tier could be, conceivably, some results of negotiations at industry or enterprise level.

The Government will discuss that approach with the ACTU and the employers next week. The ACTU has already expressed the opinion that it sees some benefits in moving to a different system from the one that currently exists. Employer organisations are also developing something along these lines, so I am quite optimistic that we can have a substantial degree of agreement between all parties-government, unions and employers-about the kind of wage fixing system which should operate in 1987. That does not mean we will have agreement about everything. It is highly unlikely that we would have exact agreement about all the details of the system or about the outcome, but there can be substantial agreement about the kind of wage fixing system that will apply in the future. That is something that we have not had in the past and I believe it will be a substantial step forward. We will discuss this matter with the ACTU and the employers next week. After we have had those discussions we will know exactly how much we are likely to achieve. I believe we will be able to change the wage fixing system to a system which enables us to have an overall wages outcome which is compatible with continued economic recovery. That, of course, is our overwhelming objective in the wage fixing area.

TALK.START.PARA: —Does the Minister for Foreign Affairs rate as high the prospects for a successful outcome to preliminary talks at Reykjavik between President Reagan and Secretary-General Gorbachev? Is he confident that this process will lead to a full summit between leaders of East and West?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Hayden The Hon W.G.

TALK.START.PARA: —I sincerely trust that the prospects are very good for developments which will lead to a full summit between East and West and, accordingly, I trust that the high hopes I have for the outcome of the meeting at Reykjavik will be justified. The meeting will take place on 11 and 12 October. As the Prime Minister has said, the Reykjavik meeting will provide an historic opportunity for the leaders to restore stability and to give clear directions towards progress on arms control.

ANSWER.PARA: While at the United Nations in New York I had the opportunity of discussing the prospects of a summit meeting between the President of the United States of America and the Secretary-General of the Soviet Union with both President Reagan and Secretary of State Shultz on 21 September, then on 25 September with Foreign Minister Shevardnadze of the Soviet Union. The thing which struck me was the dramatically changed mood in respect of both sides. It was positive and hopeful, but of course was conditioned by a recognition of the enormous complexity and difficulty of the challenge ahead.

The asymmetrical deployment of nuclear weapons between the two countries will be the most notable difficulty with which they will have to contend as, one hopes, they move towards some sort of system of arms control. The Soviet Union has an overwhelming deployment of intercontinental ballistic missiles, which of course creates great distress to the United States because these ICBMs have enormously improved accuracy and explosive fire power. Accordingly, in the view of the United States they are a threat to its silo based, land based missiles. On the other hand, the United States has an extensive and effective deployment of submarine launched ballistic missiles which are part of its nuclear deterrents and these are seen by the Soviet Union as a threat.

The matter of compiling a symmetrical balance between these sorts of things in order to arrive at a mutually acceptable arrangement for arms control represents one of the great challenges. Similarly, the intermediate nuclear force deployment in Europe, where I think there may be some prospect of a substantial basis for negotiation, nonetheless represents a critical challenge. The deployment of these weapons in Asia greatly concerns Japan-that is understandable. More than that, the weapons are mobile or can be made mobile and can be targeted on Europe, so they represent a destabilising or unbalancing factor in any negotiations.

The important fact is that both sides have recognised the need for reservations, restraints and certain conditionality so that these talks can start. My impression is clearly one of a positive commitment from both East and West to try to sort out a worthwhile result, so the Reykjavik meeting is extremely important. I should mention that the Prime Minister has written to both President Reagan and Secretary-General Gorbachev outlining a number of proposals which he believes-I thoroughly endorse that belief-are essential in the process of negotiations either at Reykjavik or subsequently. The Government also hopes for progress on other items of the agenda, such as human rights, East-West bilateral relations and the resolution of regional conflicts in places such as Cambodia and Afghanistan.

I mention two things in relation to those matters. On 21 September Australia was invited for the first time to participate in a debriefing meeting conducted by President Reagan, in which Secretary of State Shultz participated. This was a debriefing for North Atlantic Treaty Organisation countries and Japan. I say `for the first time' because Australia had never been invited to these sorts of debriefings in the past. The meeting related to progress on talks between President Reagan and Mr Shevardnadze up to that point. This was an extremely important meeting and it is a clear indication of the importance and respect accorded to Australia and its role in this area by the United States that we were invited to such a debriefing for the first time. Similarly, the extensive consultations we engaged in with Mr Shevardnadze are further evidence that both super-powers extend that respect and regard to us and want to involve us in the process of developments arising from summitry.

The final matter is that on 15 October Mr Kenneth Adelman, the Director of the United States Arms Control and Disarmament Agency, will come to this country hot on the heels of the conclusion of the Reykjavik pre-summit discussions. His purpose will be to debrief the Government. The Prime Minister, the Minister for Defence and I will be participating in that debriefing. That is pretty clear evidence that the role Australia has properly sought to carve for itself in having a right to participate in arms control and disarmament matters is recognised, respected and encouraged by the super-powers.

TALK.START.PARA: —Madam Speaker, I seek your indulgence to say that, although it will not surprise the House for me to say that the Opposition and I do not necessarily share the analysis just given by the Foreign Minister, certainly the Opposition shares the hope of the Government that the Reykjavik meeting between President Reagan and Mr Gorbachev is productive along the hard march to achieving an effective arms limitation agreement between the super-powers.

—My question is directed to the Minister for Foreign Affairs. I join with the Leader of the Opposition in endorsing his hopes for the meeting between President Reagan and Mr Gorbachev. The Minister referred in his lengthy answer to his meeting with Soviet Foreign Minister Shevardnadze on 25 September. Bearing in mind that he said that at his previous meetings with Soviet officials he has never had time to raise the issue of Soviet occupation of Afghanistan, did he raise it on this occasion?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Hayden The Hon W.G.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr Speaker--

ANSWER.PARA: Honourable members interjecting-

TALK.START.PARA: —With me looking at you with my spectacles on and you looking at me with your spectacles on, I am getting a better view; Madam Speaker, I apologise.
—Flattery will get you everywhere.

—Well, what could one expect from a working class boy from Ipswich. If I have said in the past that I have not had time to raise Afghanistan with Soviet officials, I was wrong. I was caught off step one day, I must confess. I did publicly raise Afghanistan with Mr Gromyko at a luncheon when I outlined in my formal responses our opposition to Soviet occupation of Afghanistan. The question is whether I raised Afghanistan on this occasion. I mentioned in passing our concern about Afghanistan, Vietnam and a whole range of matters, but I focused on the main matters in a meeting which went nearly 30 minutes over time. We had one hour set aside for the meeting and the fact that we had so much extra time is an indication of the importance with which the dialogue was regarded by both sides. I had to concentrate my attention on a selection of matters, mainly arms control and disarmament; regional matters, following Vladivostok. The speech of Soviet Secretary-General Gorbachev at Vladivostok was a speech which, when one takes the polemics away to one side and looks at the content, is a most significant and important speech and offers many positive proposals which could be followed up, especially within the regional context; in particular to focus on our immediate region, the South Pacific and so on. Those things were attended to in greater detail. The Sino-Soviet dispute, Afghanistan, Cambodia and Vietnam were mentioned, although I must confess only quickly, in passing, because it was more essential to focus on the big issues of the moment.
