TALK.START.PARA: —by leave-Madam Speaker, it gives me great pleasure to be able to table for the information of honourable members the first volume of the final report of the Better Health Commission entitled `Looking Forward to Better Health'. The remaining two volumes will be tabled as soon as the printing is finalised.

SPEECH.PARA: Let me now turn to the Commission itself. Honourable members will recall that I established the Commission early in 1985 and it began its work in March 1985. Its role was to inquire into the current health status of the Australian population and recommend national health goals, priorities and programs to achieve significant improvements in illness prevention and health awareness in Australia. The Commission was chaired by Professor Derek Llewellyn-Jones and had a range of prominent Australians as its members. I would like to take this opportunity to thank the commissioners for the way in which they went about their work and for producing such a detailed but highly readable report. That easy style should ensure that it is widely read across Australia as it is, after all, discussing possibly Australia's most valuable resource-the health of us all. The better health report is possibly the most significant report tabled on the subject of health in Australia to date. It is important because it has the potential to provide a turning point in health policy

Health care planning and policy up until now has, in the main, concerned itself with problems associated with the payment of health professionals and with caring for those who were ill. Consequently much of our effort has been devoted to how we pay doctors, how we pay for hospitals, how we pay for our medicines. Illness has absorbed the lion's share of the resources available to health. The sick are now protected under Medicare, and this Government has taken this initiative to promote better health in the community, to address the problem of preventing ill-health. My Department has recently been reorganised to adjust its focus towards better health, and a health advancement division has been established to promote these policies. Such policies are life saving, life enhancing and promise to cut, in the long term, the costs of ill health.

The report makes a number of tough observations, which I would like to draw to the attention of honourable members: There is no national focus on illness prevention in Australia; there are no national directions, strategies, objectives or goals; medical schools fail to train students to promote health; research into illness prevention is fragmented and sparse-it lacks priorities and is rarely evaluated; national, State and Territory funding for illness prevention is small and erratic; information and skills sharing is limited; and the media do not appreciate their potential to contribute to better health.

It is easy to be complacent about the state of the nation's health. True, we have made many advances, but it is salutary to remember that: Heart attacks, strokes, cancers and accidents account for 75 per cent of all deaths in Australia, most of which diseases are, to a significant extent, preventable; Australia still ranks high as a nation of pill poppers, with 74 per cent of women and 60 per cent of men currently taking medication; smoking is the regular habit of 32 per cent of men and 25 per cent of women-worse still the number of young smokers is growing; diet related disease accounts for about 60 per cent of deaths; over two-thirds of Australians rarely undertake vigorous weekly exercise; and one in six men and one in eight women have high blood pressure.
Contribution to Health Policy

Madam Speaker, Australia cannot afford to ignore these facts any longer. This report deals with prevention, not cure; with people, not patients; it asks us to focus our attention on preventive rather than curative medicine. The Commission found that health is a fundamental concern to all Australians. Most of those who submitted evidence to the Commission saw the need for a new positive direction in our attitude to health and for an increased emphasis on illness prevention and community participation in health policy. I expect the report will provide a catalyst for debate and action on better health in Australia. The Commission has already raised the level of debate in the area of prevention of illness and the promotion of health. The community reaction to the Commission is worth noting. Over 500 written submissions were received from all areas of Australia and on a broad range of health topics. Over 300 individuals and organisations presented oral evidence.

The Commission also felt that it was necessary to investigate a number of other areas further and held a series of workshops, study groups, and seminars for this purpose. In February of this year the Commission published its interim report. Over 1,000 copies of the report were distributed for comment to individuals and groups who had made substantial contributions to the Commission or had shown interest in the Commission's work. Over 150 written replies to that interim report were received, and these were considered by the Commission when preparing its final report.

Another significant contribution made by the better health report is that it provides us with an up to date profile on the status of our health. According to one survey conducted by the Commission, three-quarters of Australians admit that they could improve their health by changes to their lifestyle and behaviour. Almost two-thirds of the population feel they have almost complete control over their own health. This is a very encouraging basis on which to mount a national better health campaign. The report also provides a very useful discussion on existing barriers to achieving better health.

As part of its terms of reference, the Commission was asked to consider the special needs of a number of specific groups within the Australian community, including Aborigines, people with disabilities, immigrants, older people, women and youth. The contribution of the Commission in this area will provide an invaluable foundation for planning future health promotion and illness prevention activities. The report looks at a number of important specific settings for health and recommends actions necessary in each case. These areas include: The involvement of children at school and the training of professionals in prevention at universities and colleges; the provision of incentives to health professions to promote prevention; the role of the media, both positive and negative, in prevention activities; and the role of research and the evaluation of what is being done. The Commission has made a number of recommendations in each of these areas.
National Goals

In its terms of reference the Commission was also asked to recommend national health goals, priorities and programs. The Commission, after considerable discussion, identified six priority areas for action. These were: Cardiovascular disease, nutrition, injury, cancer, communicable diseases and mental health. Having established the priorities, the Commission formed three task forces in the areas of cardiovascular disease, nutrition and injury. The task force process was used by the Commission to demonstrate one approach to the setting of national goals and the targets and strategies needed to achieve these goals. Each task force has set out measurable goals for the year 2000 and a blueprint, year by year, on how to achieve those goals.
Some of these measurable goals include:

reduction of the number of smokers to 15 per cent of the population-presently one-third of all adult Australians are smokers; reduction of the proportion of adults who have persistent high blood pressure to less than 5 per cent of the population; reduction in the prevalence of those suffering from overweight and obesity from the present 38 per cent of the population to 25 per cent; reduction to 5 per cent of the contribution of alcoholic beverages to the total energy content of the Australian diet;

an increase in the level of breast-feeding at three months of life from 50 per cent to 80 per cent; to reduce by 50 per cent the numbers of hospital admissions of children for accidental poisonings from drugs and household poisons; and a reduction in the number of alcohol-related road crashes by 15 per cent.

These are some of the targets which the Commission wants to see achieved by the year 2000. We now have the base data on these targets, and I have asked the Secretary to my Department to include in the annual report a progress statement to monitor what has been achieved, what has been spent and what is planned in the area of better health each year.

It should be noted that a number of the recommendations of the Commission are already being implemented as a result of this Government's initiatives in the past two years to shift the emphasis from a curative to a preventive approach and to fill obvious but neglected gaps within the health system. There have been essentially separate but complementary developments in areas such as community health, public health, health services research, health promotion and other related activities. These initiatives all share the same basic objective of achieving better health for Australians. I have asked my Department to explore how these related activities might be interwoven to give a more coherent national focus to prevention as part of a new public health strategy for Australia.

A central recommendation of the Commission was the establishment of a new and independent national body to provide leadership for better health. The need for effective national machinery is imperative. A workable partnership between relevant Commonwealth and State agencies has to be developed as there can be no national strategy for better health without that partnership. I intend to make this a priority item at the next Australian Health Ministers' Conference in April 1987. I should add that last week senior health officials from across Australia met and decided to establish a national health for all targets committee to follow up the Commission's work, particularly in the area of setting national goals.

Quite rightly the Better Health Commission advocates that governments should, in future, concentrate their activities in priority areas. The priority areas identified for action are cardiovascular disease, nutrition, injury, mental health, cancer and communicable diseases. This is part of the national strategy I will be canvassing at the next Australian Health Ministers' Conference. A number of State health authorities have recently published planning documents which outline their priorities. All seem to be remar- kably consistent and I am hopeful we can achieve an agreed national strategy which will enable us to meet the goals set by the Commission's taskforce groups for the year 2000.

The Commission's recommendations in the area of public health are related to the findings of the Kerr White report into Research and Educational Requirements for Public Health and Tropical Health in Australia, which I recently tabled in this House. The 1986-87 Federal Budget allocated $1m for public health research and development. This money will be translated into public health fellowships and research projects as a matter of urgency.

For the first time a major national statistics collection initiative is being developed in the Australian Institute of Health. The Institute will also have a technology assessment and health services research arm. Much of the $26m Budget allocation for the Kerr White proposals will be spent on support of Masters of Public Health courses in universities around Australia, and we will also support the establishment of a centre of excellence to train public health teachers at the Australian National University. In this matter we have, I am pleased to say, pre-empted the Commission's recommendations.

Major changes in health policy, away from traditional treatment and cure values, will only take place effectively if community attitude and involvement shifts. The Commission found a significant community voice for change but a greater effort is needed to assist communities to assess their health needs and to be able to communicate those needs in a way that will be reflected in future health policy.

New channels of communication are being presently formulated within the Department of Health with the establishment of a health forum. This forum will provide consumer groups with a working mechanism to enable inputs into policy advice and administrative activities, and is, I understand, a first for consumer involvement in Departments of Health. Health professionals are vital to the cause of better health and the Commission recommendations in this area will in part be taken up by the proposed national inquiry into medical education which will be established in the near future.

The Commission also looked at a variety of incentives to encourage medical practitioners to foster prevention. In the continuing review of Medicare, these options will be kept under consideration. In August I released a report on one of these approaches, namely health maintenance organisations, and the response to such proposals suggests that increasingly the medical profession is prepared to consider alternative modes of health care delivery and different methods of paying for medical services. There has been much talk about the media's role in health and I strongly support the work of the Commission in this area. Recent results in areas such as the acquired immune deficiency syndrome and drugs have demonstrated the power of the media in establishing positive attitudinal and behavioural effects.

The Commission has recommended the foundation of a health and media council to consider major health issues in terms of their impact on the activities of the media. There can be no doubt about the importance of selling health messages, and one that readily comes to mind must be smoking. The Commission singled out smoking as a special problem and recommended a number of actions to reduce the level of smoking in Australia. I can report that State health agencies are actively engaged in a campaign to combat smoking. My Department has recently taken the initiative in working towards a smoke free workplace by the end of this year-an initiative which has attracted national interest. The National Campaign Against Drug Abuse has included smoking as one of the priority areas for action. Of course, the National Campaign Against Drug Abuse itself is a major component of the Government's efforts to improve overall health standards.

The Budget allocates $21.4m for the National Campaign Against Drug Abuse this year, $2m for a national education program on AIDS, and $1.8m for the national health promotion program, which includes funds for the development of Better Health Commission recommendations. A $1.8m grant will be made to the Australian Diabetes Foundation this year, and $1.3m has been allocated for a campaign against hepatitis B. An additional $1m will be made available for family planning services this year and $700,000 has been made available for the first stage of the Bicentennial initiative against measles.

The Commission also recommended a number of longer term funding proposals designed to provide a substantial pool of funds for better health initiatives. These include a one per cent increase in the present level of tobacco and alcohol excise; one per cent of the Medicare taxation levy; and appropriations from general revenue and tax deductible donations. Because these involve a number of portfolios and will have major fiscal impact, these recommendations will be matters for consideration in the 1987-88 budgetary context.

The most important question is where do we go from here? How do we capitalise on this report? How do we maintain the momentum generated by the Better Health Commission? Already my Department is considering a number of impressive projects in the areas recommended for action by the Commission including school health education, community development and, of course, the priority areas of cardiovascular disease, nutrition and injury. I will be making an announcement towards the end of this year in relation to the allocation of $1m provided in this Budget to implement some of the Better Health Commission findings. Non-committed funds under the national health promotion program for 1986-87 estimated at $300,000 will also be allocated in a manner consistent with the findings of the Better Health Commission. When my Department has examined the report in detail and has related its findings to other public health initiatives and there has been sufficient time to analyse community and State reaction to the findings of the report, I will be presenting a longer term better health strategy proposal to government.

Finally, I would like to take a moment to explain the new public health strategy which has gained support around the world and to which the Better Health Commission is a contributor. The term `public health' has traditionally been associated with activities such as food inspection, sewerage control and the like. The `new' public health expands `old' public health horizons. It is a total approach to health and brings together health promotion, illness prevention, health services research, environmental and social health activities and the like under one banner. It looks at spheres of activity impacting on health-the environmental, the political, the economic, the cultural, the social, the physical and their interactions. It is, therefore, intersectoral. I would like to see Australia adopt this approach in its future health policy developments.

I conclude by saying that I believe this is a report for the people of Australia and it is my hope that they will read it and discuss it and, if possible, develop the ideas and take up the challenge that it presents. If any person or organisation would like to share their views with me, I would welcome their comments on the report. Governments can do only so much. The report is now available for everyone to consider and I believe that effective changes in public policy will only come about if the community is committed to change. I present my statement and a copy of volume 1 of the final report of the Better Health Commission.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Porter Mr J.R.

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave-The final report of the Better Health Commission is truly a product of our age. Personal awareness of the rewards of better health has never been higher. With many of the major diseases largely under control through immunisation, early detection through advances in diagnostic techniques, and treatment through pharmacological, therapeutic and surgical technology, it is not surprising that our culture and those of other developed nations are turning their attention to the pursuit of better health instead of just relying on curative medicine.

SPEECH.PARA: We enjoy being healthy and would like in our own way to stay healthy. Evidence of the growing awareness of the rewards of better health is all around us. Our demands for better nutrition are beginning to be reflected by the foods that are appearing on the shelves of our supermarkets. Our desire to be better informed is reflected in book stores in titles devoted to health and a healthy lifestyle and a myriad of self-help programs. Our awareness of the contribution of exercise to our better health is reflected in the growth of health clubs, enrolment in exercise and aerobic classes and the emergence of that new denizen of the footpaths, the jogger.

Concurrent with this overwhelming community interest in better health, we who are involved in health, its administration, financing and delivery have become acutely aware that ill-health is an ever growing cost burden, and that significant gains may be made in improving our nation's health and controlling the costs associated with disease, sickness and trauma through the promotion of better health and prevention. Under Medicare, the costs of health care are exploding and changes to Medicare must be made to contain that explosion. In addition, significant gains can be made in slowing the rate of growth in expenditures through better health promotion.

The report acknowledges the generally accepted views that there are distinct advantages in the promotion of better health. The report brings together in summary form the current views of health professionals regarding the benefits of promotion of better health. In a positive fashion, it has outlined achievable and measurable goals for the health of the nation and sets milestones for those goals against which we can measure our progress towards better health. It also highlights a number of areas of real concern and attempts to identify the reasons why we have not been more successful in promoting better health.

However, the Minister for Health (Dr Blewett), in his tabling statement, ignored the majority of the report's recommendations regarding the implementation of the policy. Predictably, the Commission has recommended an increase in Commonwealth involvement, increased community involvement, increased health education in the schools, increased emphasis on health promotion in the teaching of health professionals, increased involvement of the media, increased action in relation to cigarettes and alcohol, better statistics and more evaluation.

Also fairly predictably, the Commission, as is the wont of such commissions, has suggested a new statutory authority to continue the work of the Commission with an initial budget of $50m raised largely through increased taxation, despite the fact that the Department of Health has six divisions solely devoted to health advancement and the Government has established the new Australian Institute of Health. Nevertheless, the Commission does not believe that they are doing or can do the job and believes that we need another statutory authority called the National Council for Better Health to undertake the role together with a new Community Development Fund, a new Health and Media Council and a new National Centre for Health Statistics.

In the meantime, it has recommended that the secretariat of the Better Health Commission should be kept operative and fully staffed in order to plan the launching of a new statutory authority. The Minister is silent on these recommendations. Let me make it absolutely clear that this will not be the approach adopted by the Opposition.

Whilst we share the Commission's grave concern about the need for better health promotion which will provide advantages both for the health of the nation and for the containment of health costs, nevertheless the approach adopted by the Commission does not go to the heart of the problem. I am in no way questioning the bona fides of the members of the Commission. The thrust of a number of its recommendations is consistent with the goal of the promotion of better health, but I believe that there are better ways of achieving these goals than the expensive and bureaucratic proposals outlined in this report.

The plain fact of the matter is that, until we get our health financing arrangements right, the gains to be made in the promotion of better health through government education programs and the like will be very limited. The real problem is that within the current Medicare system there are no ways to provide financial incentives to promote better health. In fact, the existing incentives are the reverse. They encourage curative rather than preventive medicine, and foster increases rather than containment of costs. Under Medicare, doctors are paid for treating people when they are sick and generally benefits are not payable for doctors to undertake preventive medicine or health education. Under Medicare, and as a result of the Health Minister's concerted attack on doctors, the report says, at page 53:

In the current climate of distrust, many medical practitioners are wary of expanding their activities in preventive medicine because they say they fear this would be accompanied by increasing bureaucratic scrutiny.
In addition, the report states at page 52:
The current reimbursement schedule in the fee-for-service system of health care provides no financial incentive for a doctor to engage in serious health promotion.

Similarly, under Medicare, hospitals are paid more the longer a patient stays in, so there is little financial incentive to reduce hospital stays. Better health promotion and cost containment measures without appropriate financial incentives as a driving force are doomed to remain in a relative backwater. As long as the Medicare program maintains its monopolistic control over payments to doctors and hospital services to public patients, it is doubtful whether the incentives for better health and health prevention will ever be achieved. The health maintenance organisation and day surgery concepts are mere shells without the motivation which has made them successful in other health care systems.

Before such initiatives can become a force for change in Australia, financial incentives must be provided to doctors which will encourage the aggressive pursuit of better health promotion initiatives, whatever form those initiatives may take. The people of Australia will also have to be provided with financial incentives in terms of cost savings as a direct result of their better health. Under Medicare, nearly all Australians have more money spent on them by the Government than they pay by way of the Medicare levy. In this situation it is virtually impossible for them to identify with any cost savings which will result from their pursuit of better health.

It is clear that the Commission was hog tied by the current Medicare arrangement and felt unable to recommend change in that area. Its failure to do so undermines the value of the report. The Government, of course, refused to put on the Commission a representative of the private health insurance industry, thereby ensuring that the Commission did not have the benefit of those operating in the field, whose very survival relies on providing cost effective care at the lowest premium and who have an enormous interest in the promotion of better health. Typically of this socialist Government, the private sector health funds were excluded from the Commission.

The Commission does point to the need to provide financial incentives for better health but within the context of Medicare. One of the Commission's recommendations is that the Government offer a voluntary capitation scheme enabling participating doctors to provide preventive as well as curative care. The report states that such a proposal may-`may'-be attractive to a number of doctors and their patients, but it never explains why. The report does say, however, that the proposal would fit within the current Medicare taxation levy arrangement.

If the Commission is truly convinced that such a scheme would, in fact, promote better health and provide cost savings to the membership, why, within the broad parameters of its terms of reference, was it unable to take that ultimate step and recommend that the members of such a program be entitled to share in the savings generated by their membership in such a program? In fact, the Commission's voluntary capitation proposal looks all the world to me like a variation on the British national health scheme, which is hardly the model we would want to follow. The difference, of course, in the United Kingdom is that one is stuck with the national health scheme, whereas this proposal is for voluntary participation.

The Commission suggests one of the most significant developments in the area of the promotion of better health is through health maintenance organisations. In August, the Federal Government released its policy statement on the role of the health maintenance organisations in Australian health. Because this policy is so firmly rooted in the Government's commitment to the financing and delivery of health services within the constraints of the Medicare program, the best features of the health maintenance organisation concept were sacrificed at the altar of the Medicare program.

It is only in a competitive private sector environment that the forces for the promotion of better health and the resultant cost containment will be maximised. Financial incentives need to be provided for doctors to keep people well and out of hospital rather than only treat them when they are sick. We need to provide incentives to maximise efficient care and reduce hospital costs. We need to provide opportunities for the financial benefits of programs which keep health costs down to be passed on to those who join such programs. We need to promote better health. Regrettably this report does not come to grips with these basic problems because Medicare provides incentives for overutilisation and penalises many health professionals who wish to promote better health.

The coalition is determined to create an environment in which there are financial incentives for the promotion of better health to contain costs whilst providing greater access to high quality care by allowing people to opt out of Medicare and by freeing up the private health insurance market. In this way I have no doubt that the private sector will provide alternative health insurance arrangements which will promote better health practices in order that they-that is the insurers-may be able to offer contributors lower premiums. In that way all involved in the delivery of health services will benefit.

DEBATE.TITLE: GENERAL AGREEMENT ON TARIFFS AND TRADE MINISTERIAL MEETING, PUNTA DEL ESTE, URUGUAY

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Dawkins The Hon J.S.

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave-I wish to make a statement on the outcome of the General Agreement on Tariffs and Trade Ministerial Meeting at Punta del Este, Uruguay, from 15 to 20 September 1986. Three weeks ago at Punta del Este, Uruguay. I participated in a GATT ministerial meeting where agreement was reached to launch a new comprehensive round of multilateral trade negotiations. The launching of the `Uruguay Round', as it will be known, is a major victory for those of us seeking to reinforce a more liberal, fair and open multilateral trading system. We achieved what many thought was impossible-an international commitment to resist protectionism, to strengthen and improve existing trading rules, and to expand the multilateral trading rules to cover major areas currently not subject to GATT disciplines. I interpolate for a moment to quote from a letter I received today from Clayton Yeutter, the United States of America Trade Representative, in which, amongst other things, he stated:

SPEECH.PARA: We achieved what many thought was impossible-an international commitment to resist protectionism, strengthen existing rules, and expand the GATT to cover major areas not currently under effective multilateral disciplines. Punta del Este was truly a victory for the principles of free and fair trade.

There were two main achievements in this regard. First, we started the process of establishing international rules for the so-called `new areas'-principally trade in services. Secondly, we provided a basis to bring effectively into the GATT framework for the first time the longstanding issue of equitable treatment for agricultural trade. A measure of this second achievement is that since the inception of the GATT in 1948 there have been no less than nine failed attempts to bring agriculture under effective GATT disciplines. There were the seven post-war MTN rounds, the 1954-55 review session at which the United States achieved a further erosion of agricultural trade rules by obtaining a waiver from the existing permissive rules and then there was the disastrous 1982 GATT ministerial meeting.

In my statement on trade policy in this chamber on 20 February this year, I stressed the important opportunity provided by a new round of multilateral trade negotiations to focus attention on the current bias in the rules against agricultural trade. The new round also provides Australia with an opportunity to create conditions for improved export performance in the fastest growing areas of world trade-manufactures and services. The creation of such conditions is concomitant with the Government's industry and trade policy objectives-as is the need to reduce the structural distortions plaguing commodity markets.

I am pleased to report that we came away from the Punta del Este ministerial meeting having achieved all of the objectives we identified for a satisfactory launching of negotiations. Multilateral trade negotiations will soon get under way on the full range of international trade problems confronting us. Certainly the decision to launch a new trade round taken at Punta de Este will not solve all our problems. The agricultural subsidies war continues. Enormous stocks of agricultural commodities continue to overhang the world market. Protectionist pressures are still evident throughout the world, and the situation could deteriorate further before improving. The importance of achieving the commencement of the `Uruguay Round' of multilateral trade negotiations lies in its unmistakable signal of a change in direction. Peace talks have finally begun and the problems have been acknowledged. To this extent we can look to the future with a measure of confidence rather than despair.

But let there be no doubt about it-the negotiations will be tough. Changing a trading environment nurtured by 40 years of distortion in the rules represents a formidable challenge. Yet we are optimistic that these negotiations will produce multilateral agreement on new rules and disciplines that will open significant new opportunities for Australian exporters and strengthen the global trading system. We seek a substantial move towards trading based on comparative advantage; an environment where Australian exporters can compete on fair terms. The meeting in Uruguay followed seven months of preparatory discussions in Geneva. Australia's strategy throughout that preparatory process was to co-operate fully with other like-minded countries to ensure that our views were heard and our aspirations taken into account. Particularly, we were determined that any new round should seriously tackle the growing crisis surrounding agricultural trade issues.

Agriculture still accounts for nearly 40 per cent of Australia's export revenue. Yet poor returns are threatening the well-being of our agricultural sector and our farmers in particular. One major factor stands out above all others as the principal cause of declining agricultural commodity prices. It is the protection and production subsidies of Europe and the United States which have encouraged more production and investment than has been warranted-production creating surpluses which have then been placed on world markets with the aid of export subsidies. Depressed prices for fair traders, such as Australia, have been the most discernible result. Similar policies have denied us legitimate access to other affluent markets such as Japan.

The critical need for Australia to address the problem is well documented. But there is an equal urgency for the European Community and the United States. Neither they, nor indeed the world, can afford to sustain the costs of the rapidly escalating subsidy warfare. The budget cost of all subsidies provided by the EC, Japan and the US to their farmers is phenomenal-an estimated $US76 billion from their combined coffers in 1986, following on $US60 billion last year. The US accounts for $US35 billion of that, Japan $US18 billion and the EC $US23 billion. But it does not end there. If consumer transfers are added, the total cost of subsidies for the three majors approaches $US180 billion. Add taxation and the contributions of individual member states and US individual State governments, and the total climbs towards a staggering $US200 billion. It is the impact of these sums that is forcing a growing international appreciation of the need to tackle the problems facing agriculture. Yet still, before Punta del Este, smaller trading nations acting alone were unable to bring these issues into a focus sharp enough to attract the attention of the major trading economies.

In the lead-up to the ministerial talks some of these smaller nations such as Australia, Uruguay, Argentina and Thailand worked long and hard, and indeed, effectively, to bring these issues to the negotiating table. Our shared desire to build a `third force' on agricultural trade issues motivated our initiative for an agricultural fair traders ministerial meeting at Cairns in August. In no small measure the success achieved on the negotiating mandate for agriculture at Punta del Este can be attributed to the solidarity and vitality of the Cairns group of fair trading nations. For the first time, smaller agricultural exporters as a group became an effective voice in the negotiations. For the first time, the focus was too sharp to ignore.

The unity and resolve of the group surprised many. The pivotal role it played in the week-long process of intensive bargaining and negotiation surprised even more. Our rapid establishment as a third agricultural force allowed us to retain the initiative in the crucial eleventh hour deliberations with the major economies. As a result we achieved a negotiating mandate, a mandate which for the first time embraces all subsidies-direct and indirect, including export subsidies. It has shifted the focus towards the root causes of the current agricultural crisis and the need to reduce and eliminate these negative distorting influences. That mandate has been clearly recognised by the major protagonists in the current subsidy war.

The EC's Commissioner de Clercq told the final plenary at Punta del Este that, while the EC's fundamental common policies and mechanisms were not up for negotiation, `agriculture will be fairly and squarely addressed in the Uruguay round-in our own interest as well as in that of other contracting parties'. United States Trade Representative Clayton Yeutter, while conceding that it would be several years before the GATT negotiations themselves bore fruit, said that `in the interim, the United States will continue to pursue policies that enhance free and fair trade, including the aggressive enforcement of United States laws that address the problem of unfair trading practices by our trading partners'. So the signs are all good, but we too will be expected to demonstrate our commitment to the negotiating process.

The reforms and benefits being sought in the negotiating round, if achieved, will not be costless. All participants will be required to accept some discipline in return for benefits received. The Cairns group has agreed to continue meeting regularly in Geneva in the course of the negotiating process and also at ministerial level as circumstances require. In so doing, it is demonstrating its commitment to ensuring that the momentum and spirit of Punta del Este is sustained. The ability to harness the strength of the combined forces of the smaller agricultural exporting nations has been clearly established. We must continue to not only maintain but also build on that new-found strength. Australia will continue to chair the Cairns group and my Department will provide the necessary secretariat to facilitate continued co-operation and liaison both within its membership and in its dealings with the major trading economies.

The Uruguay declaration introduces some hope where before was only despair. There is now a commitment to negotiate on a broad range of old and new trade policy issues and the chance to redress past inequalities and create an environment for more dynamic world trade growth in the future. It is a commendable commitment of political will. That commitment will have to be sustained and reinforced over the next four years. For the negotiations to be successful, there will need to be a determined commitment to seek domestic policy adjustments and reforms. The recognition that radical changes have to be faced is an enormous step. It establishes an environment where national policy makers will look at their policy prescriptions in a new light.

In agriculture, this will also enable us to approach the shorter term surplus problems with more assurance and sense. The Australian Government will be actively pursuing all avenues to redress current trading problems in the months ahead. Naturally, there was a reluctance to adopt such a broad mandate. Some developing countries in our own region had misgivings about a negotiation that would inevitably touch into the area of domestic policy formulation. These concerns have been covered by reference to the special position of developing countries. Certainly, we would not expect negotiated outcomes to apply with the same intensity to the modest support programs in these countries as would be expected from all industrialised countries and the more affluent newly industrialised countries.
Services

The launching of negotiations on services is another important achievement of the Punta del Este meeting, and again an historic precedent was set. For the first time we have an international consensus to consider the liberalisation of markets for service industries and to examine the scope for legally binding rules governing such trade. The services sector is a particularly important sector of the Australian economy. Services now account for 75 per cent of Australian employment and about 65 per cent of gross domestic product. Although Australia has not to date performed well in international trade in services, the sector is well placed to take advantage of Australia's improved competitive circumstances. Changes instituted by this Government in the area of financial services, and the vitality this has injected into that sector, signal the confidence with which we can approach these negotiations. Although that represents only a first step, our potential to develop into a significant trading force in the sector is beyond doubt. Certainly our ability to compete in a more open, non-discriminatory international services trade sector will be one of the major challenges faced by Australia in the coming years-a challenge we cannot afford to ignore. It offers more potential to accelerate growth for Australia's export receipts than any other industry sector.
Market Access

The ministerial declaration calls for negotiations to expand market access by reducing both tariff and non-tariff barriers to trade, and to liberalise trade in tropical products and national resource-based products. Australia is prepared to participate fully in these negotiations. They offer a valuable opportunity to reinforce the Government's domestic policies aimed at improved the international competitiveness of Australian industry and the gradual development of an outward orientated industrial structure. Other key features for Australia of the Uruguay round agenda include undertakings to improve existing GATT articles and codes, particularly the subsidies code, negotiate a comprehensive safeguards agreement on emergency protection arrangements, improve the rules and procedures of the dispute settlement process and look at other ways of improving the GATT institutional framework. This is a broad reaching and complex agenda.
Time Frame

Ministers established a trade negotiations committee to oversee the negotiations in the round. Between now and the end of the year the TNC will complete an organisational structure for negotiations and appoint those who will chair the various negotiating groups. We anticipate that substantive negotiations will be well under way by early next year with a four-year target date for completion. However, in some areas of the negotiations, particularly agriculture, the urgency of the problems are such that we will be seeking concrete results from the negotiations as soon as possible. The United States has been advocating a special fast track for agriculture. Australia, and the Cairns group, fully supports this objective. In that light, the Cairns group will be pressing for completion of the negotiations on agriculture within two years. The negotiations will vary in length and tempo according to subject. The ministerial declaration notes that agreements reached at an early stage may be implemented on a provisional or definitive basis prior to the formal conclusion of the negotiations. Australia, in concert with the Cairns group, regional partners and other like-minded countries, will be pressing for the earliest possible negotiated settlements. Even in that case, however, it is likely that implementation of these settlements would take place over several years.

The real success of Punta del Este is that a new round of trade negotiations has been launched encompassing critically important areas of trade for Australia in a much more comprehensive manner than has been the case in the past. It is therefore central to Australia's current economic circumstances. It offers the prospect within the foreseeable future of a new world trading order that would allow Australia to realise its competitive advantage in agriculture, and would give a major stimulus to employment, investment, and general economic growth. In short, the Uruguay round of GATT negotiations holds the prospect of a higher standard of living for all Australians. Our task in Geneva is to turn that promise into a reality. We have a long way to go, but we are well positioned for what lies ahead. While there will continue to be frustrations, disappointments and reverses, there is now some room for optimism that world trade can be placed on a more equitable basis for smaller trading countries like Australia. I table the full text of the ministerial declaration.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Braithwaite Mr R.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave-Firstly, let me say that the Opposition endorses multilateral negotiations directed towards the liberalisation of world trade. Indeed, the Government has enjoyed broad bipartisan support and encouragement from the Opposition for its initiatives in this area. The Opposition welcomes the Cairns fair traders initiative and it supported the position adopted by Australia at the Multinational Trade Negotiations ministerial meeting at Punta del Este in Uruguay. I say to the Minister for Trade (Mr Dawkins) that he deserves our sincere congratulations on the role that he played at both the Cairns and Punta del Este conferences. We are sincere in that. I believe he has been able to give Australia a position in world trade that we may not have had before.

SPEECH.PARA: It is rather unfortunate that the move by the European Economic Community to undercut the United States offer of cheap wheat to the Soviet Union perhaps eclipsed to an extent the publicity that the Minister deserved. But that only underscores the reality of the world in which we live and of the trade war that continues in its undisciplined way despite all of the summits, meetings, deliberations and declarations that take place. It is true to say that the outcomes achieved at both Cairns and Punta del Este were constructive and certainly better than was generally expected. Again, I say that the Minister is to be congratulated on what he has achieved. Without detracting from that achievement, I wish to offer some commentary on what was achieved and on how perhaps even better results might have been achieved. I admit, however, that bearing in mind the location of the meeting, the results may not have been improved.

The Cairns meeting of the 14 non-subsidising agricultural exporting or fair trading nations in late August was a very bold initiative that the Opposition fully supported. The idea was to bring together countries which, with Australia, contribute about 22 per cent of the world's agricultural trade, making this group the third largest bloc. The aim of these countries, which suffer the ravages of European Economic Community, United States and Japanese protectionism was to forge an alliance to press for the liberalisation of agricultural trade.

The specific focus was to press for the adoption in Punta del Este, Uruguay, of a tough text on agricultural subsidies to be included on the agenda for the upcoming MTN round. The state of play before Cairns was that 48 countries had registered some degree of commitment to the so-called Swiss-Colombian text on agricultural trade. However, from our point of view, that Swiss-Colombian draft was deficient. It contained no definite commitment to abolish agricultural subsidies, only consideration of a possible phased reduction in subsidies.

The declaration issued by the fair traders at the end of the Cairns conference was therefore an achievement. By contrast, it called for priority to be given to discussions on agricultural subsidies in the MTN, for the removal of market access barriers, substantial reductions in agricultural subsidies and the elimination of those subsidies within an agreed period. Certainly it was a tough text. Just as importantly, it gained the support of Canada, a country which trades heavily with the United States and New Zealand and which has access to the EEC markets.

At the time of the Cairns fair traders meeting I called on the Government to work to try to get other countries to endorse the Cairns initiative in the three weeks left before the MTN conference. It is unfortunate that that suggestion was not followed. It was unfortunate because I believe the Government lost an opportunity to broaden support for the Cairns group and to strengthen our negotiating position in Uruguay. I also believe that the Government should have acted to stiffen Canada's resolve. Shortly after the meeting in Cairns, Canada withdrew support for the text that had been agreed to in favour of the deficient Swiss-Colombian draft. The solidarity of the fair traders was then in doubt. It would have been of some concern that the opening speeches at Punta del Este actually saw two Cairns participants, Canada and Colombia, retreat from the Cairns declaration. Those countries urged delegates to support the Swiss-Colombian draft with its weaker text on possible reduction of agricultural subsidies.

By the middle of the Punta del Este talks, even the tacit support given by the United States for the fair traders position was wavering. The United States special trade representatives urged delegates to stick to the Swiss-Colombian draft previously agreed to by 48 countries. The reason given was: `If we start changing the text it will begin unravelling and we may never get any agreement'. As the conference was moving towards the compromise solution of the Swiss-Colombian draft, the success of the fair traders was in balance. It is perhaps not exaggerating too much to say that the future of fair agricultural trade was also in the balance.

Fortunately, France, the main proponent of subsidies, cracked, and the EEC buckled, agreeing to put the future of its common agricultural policy on the negotiating table. That was one of the real achievements of the conference-it was a major achievement. The conference agreed to negotiate comprehensively on agriculture in the upcoming MTN round for the first time in GATT discussions.

DEBATE.TITLE: GENERAL AGREEMENT ON TARIFFS AND TRADE MINISTERIAL MEETING, PUNTA DEL ESTE, URUGUAY

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Braithwaite Mr R.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —Most significantly, the crucial paragraph in the text agreed to by delegates called for talks to `increase discipline on the use of all direct and indirect subsidies and other measures affecting agriculture, including their phased reduction of their negative effects and dealing with their causes'. It is fair to say that this would not have been achieved without the Cairns fair traders initiative and without the moral support of the United States of America. These events make the results of Punta del Este all the more significant, particularly in view of the role played by Australia and the Minister.

SPEECH.PARA: The Punta del Este text may not be perfect but it is significantly stronger than the proposed Swiss-Colombian draft. While an even better text, possibly including a time frame for the negotiations on agricultural subsidies, might have been gained had the Government broadened support for the Cairns declaration prior to the Punta del Este conference, the final outcome was welcome. As the Minister indicates, it represents an historic turning point following the nine failed earlier attempts at such negotiations. But, as the Deputy Leader of the National Party of Australia (Mr Hunt) has stated, the battle to resolve the subsidies problem will be long and hard.

Caution has to be issued in that there has been no agreement to abolish subsidies at this stage. What we have is an agreement to talk about subsidies and those talks can be expected to run for at least the full four years. In the wake of this historic agreement at Punta del Este, I call on the Government to consolidate and seek to broaden the fair traders group so as to increase its influence in the tough years of negotiation ahead. I am pleased to note from the Minister's statement today that the Cairns group will continue to meet to ensure that its strength and momentum are maintained. The fact that Australia will continue to chair the Cairns group is also a tremendous achievement because Australia is again seen to be leading by example. I am particularly heartened by the Minister's statement that we must continue not only to maintain but also to build on this newfound strength. I hope that this means that he will now attempt to broaden the membership of the Cairns group and popularise its aims.

The EEC cannot be taken for granted, even though it gave support in Uruguay. The concession it actually made was to talk about subsidies. The importance of maintaining the solidarity and expanding the membership and influence of the Cairns group will be paramount in the coming months and years. Unfortunately, the forces of protectionism throughout the world appear to be mounting. I believe that essentially Australia has the support of the United States in its stand on agricultural subsidies. Until recently the United States, like Australia, had virtuously adhered to the principles of GATT. This has cost both our countries dearly. But the United States is increasingly being dragged into a trade war with the European Economic Community whereby smaller agricultural exporting countries like Australia become cannon fodder.

I was interested to hear the analogy that the Minister made with Kings Cross during the conference. Perhaps we could compare the EEC with a lady of the night in Kings Cross insofar as world trade is concerned-a person prepared to sell her wares anywhere, at any time, at any price and under any circumstances. The recent subsidised sale of wheat to Russia, which undercut the United States offer, is an example of that activity. In fact, page 5 of the Minister's statement indicates the cost of subsidies to nations throughout the world. Australia played its part with the Bureau of Agricultural Economics survey. The cost to farmers of the EEC is $1 billion per year. I believe that that fact has to be given wider circulation in order to bring this point home. But it is evidence again of Australia's concern.

While Australia must be prepared to forge ahead with the Cairns group, it must also be prepared to negotiate with the United States to mitigate the effects of its export enhancement program, market loan program and other protectionist measures. This must be done on a bipartisan basis.

I wish to comment briefly on the success of the all-party delegation which visited the United States of America and which demonstrates the sense of such an approach. The delegation succeeded in stopping the Dole amendment and defeating the legislation which proposed subsidised wheat sales and would have mauled Australian wheat farmers. Although we should not run off to America every time there is panic over one of our markets, there is reason to keep open this window into the United States in connection with other moves. There are moves that need careful watching, one of which is the sugar import quota. It is suggested that Australia will lose that quota of 142,000 tonnes in preference to the Philippines, Ecuador and Caribbean countries. It is important that, although the Helms-Melcher amendment was defeated, this matter should be borne in mind because the warning has been given and similar problems could arise again. The United States sugar quota is most important. There is also concern about a move to control lamb imports into the United States, by having lamb included with beef in meat import control provisions under a United States trade Bill. This matter arose earlier in the year and was knocked out in a similar way to the sugar quota. That problem still exists and these considerations will have to be watched from a bipartisan viewpoint. Parliamentary delegations appear to be able to size up a situation and to have a better effect than other types of negotiation.

On the subject of bipartisanship, I conclude by welcoming today's call by the Minister for Trade for a determined commitment to seek domestic policy adjustments and reforms. In his statement the Minister said:
We seek a substantial move towards trading based on comparative advantage; an environment where Australian exporters can compete on fair terms.

The General Agreement on Tariffs and Trade presumes a level playing field. It appears to me that Australia among all the other nations has abided by the terms of GATT more responsibly than any other nation. But Australia even within GATT is not playing on that level playing field. For instance, we are playing against competitors in world markets and are trading with different economies that put Australia at a disadvantage. We are competing on a field in which there are differences in interest rates, inflation rates and in the rigid industrial and wages policies that are adopted between countries. Also to be borne in mind is the growing foreign debt, record budgets, and the cost to our traders of government charges and the excessive expenditure to which the Budget gives rise. Therefore, even within the terms of GATT Australia's sense of responsibility has put us at a disadvantage in many respects. Exporter costs must be considered before that playing field is levelled out. At some time in the near future the Minister may be able to explain the manner in which these domestic policy adjustments will be made and whether exporter costs will be removed.

I wish to comment on the prominence given by the Minister in his statement to the subject of services. It is important that we should regard services as an integral part of the means by which we can get the balance of trade deficit into proper perspective. This is an opportunity to make the point that not only should we be buying Australian but we should be using Australian. The services offered by our professionals and our consultants are on a par with any. I thank the Minister for what has been done and for what has been begun in the Multilateral Trade Negotiations in GATT. I assure the Minister that in a change of government we would continue the moves that he has initiated.
