PETITION.TITLE: Closure of Post Office Agencies
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable The Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled. The humble petition of the undersigned citizens of Australia respectfully showeth:

That we strenuously object to the proposal that many post office agencies are to be closed. They provide a network of offices with postal and agency services to residential areas and small communities.

They serve a community need and we would be seriously inconvenienced if forced to travel further to purchase postal items or collect parcels. It would be an unnecessary expense particularly for pensioners without their own transport.

We maintain that the purpose of post offices should be to serve the public for the variety of services they offer. They are a community centre particularly in country areas and if necessary they should be subsidised to retain them.

Your petitioners therefore humbly pray that the House should take all possible steps to prevent the closure of post office agencies and that the network should be extended, with the Agency services they officer expanded.
And your petitioners, as in duty bound, will ever pray.
PETITION.PRESENTER.BLOCK: by Mr Andrew,Mr Beale,Mr Blunt,Mr Braithwaite,Mr Ian Cameron,Mr Cobb,Mr Drummond,Dr Harry Edwards,Mr Griffiths,Mr Hawker,Mr Nehl,Mr Rocher,Mr Ruddock,Mr Shipton,Mr Simmons and Mr Uren.

PETITION.TITLE: Radioactive Substances
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled. The petition of the undersigned respectfully showeth:
We most strongly oppose the process of Food Irradiation by radioactive Cobalt 60 or any other radioactive substance.

We oppose the introduction of regulations that will facilitate the food irradiation process by State Governments. We express our deep concern at this attempt to extend the use of radioactive substances and exposure of workers to radiation.

We call on the Government to immediately ban the importation of radioactive Cobalt 60 or other radioactive substances and to immediately disallow the regulations that permit the irradiation of food here in Australia.
And your petitioners, as in duty bound, will ever pray.
PETITION.PRESENTER.BLOCK: by Mr Griffiths,Ms Jakobsen,Mr Kent,Mr Milton and Dr Theophanous.

PETITION.TITLE: Family Allowances and Spouse Rebate
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled. The petition of the undersigned shows:
Graduated family allowances are of important assistance to families with more than one child.
All family allowances, whether for one, two, three, or more children, have not kept pace with inflation.
There are suggestions that all family allowances should be paid at the one flat rate. This would severely disadvantage families with more than one child.
There are also suggestions that the dependent spouse rebate be reduced or removed. This would represent another blow to the family unit.
Your petitioners therefore pray that the House of Representatives, in Parliament assembled, should:
Ask the Federal Government to increase the value of existing family allowance payments, and
Reject any moves to change the payments to a flat rate or to tamper with the spouse rebate;
And your petitioners, as in duty bound, will ever pray.
PETITION.PRESENTER.BLOCK: by Mr Bilney,Mr Hawker and Mr Kent.

PETITION.TITLE: Family Allowances and Spouse Rebate
PETITION.PARA: The Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled.
We, the undersigned plead that the Parliament implement pro-family policies. In particular we appeal for:
1. the retention of the present graduated assessment system for payment of the Family Allowance;
2. indexation of the Family Allowance in order to keep pace with inflation;

3. an increase of 3.7% in the Family Allowance benefit to return it to 11.5% of the Average Award Wage (making it similar in value to the 11.5% of the Basic Wage when Child Endowment was first introduced by the Chifley Government in 1941).
4. retention of the Dependent Spouse Rebate and the amount of the Dependent Spouse Rebate adjusted so that it is equal in value to the tax-free threshold allowed when calculating taxable income.
Your petitioners therefore humbly pray that you will give this matter earnest consideration and your petitioners, as in duty bound, will ever pray.
PETITION.PRESENTER.BLOCK: by Mr Drummond and Mr Rocher.

PETITION.TITLE: National Flag
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled. The humble petition of the undersigned citizens of Australia showeth that whereas:
1. They are completely satisfied with the design of the existing Australian National Flag.
2. They are aware that it properly reflects the immutable characteristics of Australia namely:
(a) The Union Jack, itself the creation of three Christian Crosses, represents the nation's historical origin and the source of its language and law;
(b) The Southern Cross on an azure blue background signifying its geographical location on this planet Earth;
(c) The large star depicting the advent of Federation in 1901.
3. They know the Flag has been a source of inspir- ation to generations of Australians in peace and war.
4. They recall that millions of native-born Australians and newcomers to these shores from other parts of the world have become united under its proud symbolism.
5. They are certain that any change to the Flag will produce divisions in the Australian community.

Your petitioners therefore pray that your honourable House will propose and pass a motion that ``the existing Australian National Flag be changed only with the approval of the National as expressed in a Referendum.''
And your petitioners, as in duty bound, will ever pray.
PETITION.PRESENTER.BLOCK: by Dr Harry Edwards,Mr Hawker and Mr Shipton.

PETITION.TITLE: National Flag
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and the Members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled. The petition of certain citizens of Australia respectfully showeth:
That the Australian flag symbolises the continuity between Australia's past, its present and its future;

That the presence of the Union Jack on the flag represents not a subservience to Britain, but a reminder of our inheritance of the fruits of hundreds of years of struggle for individual liberty against the forces of tyranny and oppression;
Nonetheless recognises the rights of Australians should they wish as a people to change the design of their flag.
Your petitioners humbly pray that no change be made to the Australian flag except with the consent of the people in a referendum.
And your petitioners, as in duty bound, will every pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Fringe Benefits Tax
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and the Members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled.
We, the undersigned, are deeply concerned at the impact of the new Fringe Benefits Tax on the following grounds:
1. Its severe and damaging effect on business confidence, investment and incentive, especially in the rural, mining and small business sectors.
2. Its capacity to seriously worsen unemployment through the additional costs it imposes.
3. Its extremely negative impact on the competitiveness of export industries at a time when the nation desperately needs to improve its trading performance.

4. In that it may complete many honest and decent citizens to defy the tax in order to preserve their livelihoods, their businesses and the jobs of their employees, thus causing hardship, the breakdown of respect for the law and discord within the community.
We therefore most earnestly petition you to repeal the Fringe Benefits Tax Legislation forthwith.
And your petitioners, as in duty bound, will ever pray.
PETITION.PRESENTER.BLOCK: by Mr Braithwaite and Mr Hicks.

PETITION.TITLE: Fringe Benefits Tax
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled.
The humble petition of the undersigned citizens of Australia respectfully showeth:
1. That the Fringe Benefits Tax Assessment Bill 1986 is having a detrimental effect on the car industry generally in South Australia, and more particularly, on employment in that industry.

2. The Fringe Benefits Tax Assessment Bill 1986 contains many anomalies, inconsistencies and mistakes in drafting and its administrative implementation is an unwarranted burden on Australian businesses and the Australian taxpayer.

Your petitioners therefore humbly pray that this House repeal as a matter of utmost urgency this regressive legislation which imposes a disincentive to economic and employment growth thereby jeopardising the well-being and living standards of all Australians.
And your petitioners, as in duty bound, will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Fringe Benefits Tax
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives. The humble petition of the undersigned citizens of Australia respectfully showeth that the Fringe Benefits Tax is an iniquitous and unjust impost which will further damage the Australian economy and further increase costs to employers.
The Tax will:
(1) further increase the level of unemployment;
(2) increase the administrative costs and overheads for business and Government;
(3) particularly disadvantage small businesses and farmers; and
(4) act as a disincentive to those who are the most productive and skilled;
and we the undersigned call upon the Government to immediately repeal the Fringe Benefits Tax.
And your petitioners, as in duty bound, will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Fringe Benefits Tax
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled.
The humble petition of the undersigned citizens of Australia respectfully showeth that:

The Hawke Government's Fringe Benefits Tax is a vicious, punitive tax that unjustly affects employers, will have a major impact on small business and farm profitability, and will result in increased unemployment.
Your petitioners humbly pray that the House of Representatives, in Parliament assembled, urge the Parliament to repeal the legislation establishing the Fringe Benefits Tax.
And your petitioners, as in duty bound, will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Fringe Benefits Tax
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled.
The humble petition of the undersigned citizens of Australia respectfully showeth that:
The fringe benefits tax will cause hardship to business throughout Australia, especially in the already severely-depressed rural sector and in the motor vehicle industry.
The fringe benefits tax will be a disincentive to employment and worse, will result in additional unemployment.

The economy of this country would best be served by policies that lightened the tax burden, not increased it, that encouraged enterprise, not stifled it and stimulated growth, development and jobs, not prevented it.
Your petitioners therefore pray that the House will repeal this Legislation and your petitioners, as in duty bound, will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Tertiary Education Administration Fee
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled. This petition of the undersigned citizens of Australia respectfully showeth that:

1. The introduction of an administrative charge for annual enrolment will restrict access to higher education for a range of disadvantaged groups, particularly women, rural dwellers and some low income earners.
2. Students will be deterred from study because of the probable escalation in the charge in future Budgets, prohibiting students' ability to plan the long term costs of their education.

3. The introduction of an administrative charge is contrary to the education provisions of the ALP/ACTU Accord and ALP policy which states that the party `will maintain the provision of free tertiary education'.
Your petitioners therefore pray that the annual administrative charge for higher education students not be introduced.
And your petitioners, as in duty bound, will ever pray.
PETITION.PRESENTER.BLOCK: by Mr Cohen and Mr Langmore.

PETITION.TITLE: English as a Second Language Programs
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives of the Australian Parliament assembled. The petition of the undersigned residents of Australia respectfully showeth:
We the undersigned residents of Australia totally reject any move to cut funding to Australia-wide English as a Second Language programs in schools.
We request that the Australian Government restore funding to the 1985 level in the 1986-87 Budget.
PETITION.PRESENTER.BLOCK: by Mr Coleman and Mr Ruddock.

PETITION.TITLE: English as a Second Language Programs
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives of the Australian Parliament assembled. The petition of the undersigned residents of Australia respectfully showeth:
By drastically cutting ESL funding, you have disadvantaged thousands of Australian children.

Not only will students with limited English face gross educational inequality, but the entire Australian community will feel the wider effect-through the resultant inability of some of its citizens to contribute effectively to Australian society.

On behalf of the children who will be directly affected, and the Australian community generally, we call on you to restore full funding for the general support element of the Commonwealth ESL program.

PETITION.TITLE: Social Justice, Equity and Redistribution of Wealth
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled. We the undersigned citizens of Australia, hereby petition the Prime Minister as Leader of the Australian Labor Party in Government in Australia and humbly showeth that:

The voting public of Australia did in March 1983 and again in December 1984 vote as a majority for the election of a Labor Government who did claim to stand for social justice, equity and redistribution.
That the said voters sincerely believed that a contract was entered into in voting for a Labor Government with democratic socialist principles.

That there is an erosion of support for the pensioners, the unemployed, the aged, the sick and the working class of Australia, while the lot of the privileged class, the banks, the oil companies, and the money-changers continues to improve.

Your petitioners call on the Australian Labor Government to implement those policies and follow those principles of social justice, equity and redistribution which the majority of Australians voted for in 1983 and in 1984, and to adopt an immediate programme that will transfer the current economic burden to those better able to carry it.
And your petitioners, as in duty bound, will ever pray.
PETITION.PRESENTER.BLOCK: by Mr Kent and Mr Milton.

PETITION.TITLE: Nuclear Test Ban
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled:
This Petition of the undersigned citizens of Australia respectfully showeth that-

(1) A cessation of the testing of nuclear weapons would break the cycle of research, development and deployment of nuclear weapons and prevent the acquisition of new and ever more lethal weapons of mass destruction. It would thus be a major and significant step towards ending the arms race and beginning the disarmament process; and
(2) The Soviet Union has extended its unilateral moratorium on nuclear weapons testing until August 6 this year and has again invited the United States to cease its nuclear testing program.
Your petitioners therefore urge the Australian Government to put the strongest pressure on the United States Government to join the Soviet Union's nuclear test ban.
And your petitioners, as in duty bound, will ever pray.
PETITION.PRESENTER.BLOCK: by Mr Kent and Dr Theophanous.

PETITION.TITLE: Australian Bill of Rights Bill
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives. The petition of the undersigned respectfully showeth that the Bill of Rights is not supported by the people of Australia, and calls on the Government to:
Delay proclamation of the Bill until all matters of contention are settled by national referenda, and that:
(1) Matters of States rights, property rights, rights of the newborn, the right not to belong to unions, among other issues, have not been submitted to the people of Australia to decide, and that;
(2) No Australian Bill of Rights should depend on any foreign convention for its basis in Australian law.
And your petitioners, as in duty bound, will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Department of Immigration and Ethnic Affairs: Wollongong Area Office
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled.
The Petition of the undersigned shows:
That we the citizens of the Illawarra Region condemn the decision to close the Wollongong office of the Department of Immigration and Ethnic Affairs.
And that we respectfully request that this decision be reversed immediately.
And your petitioners, as in duty bound will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Film Censorship Board
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker, and Members of the House of Representatives of the Parliament of Australia assembled.

We, the undersigned, plead that Parliament will legislate, or act in accordance with the present legislation to replace the current members of the Film Censorship Board who have admitted to Senator Harradine on 12th December 1984 as reported in the Senate Select Committee on Video material, (see attached extracts), that they are not applying either the blasphemy or obscenity tests as required under the provision of the Customs (Cinematograph Films) Regulations, and that these persons be replaced by persons who will apply these and the other related test in accordance with the said Regulations. Your petitioners humbly pray that you will give this matter your earnest consideration, and your petitioners, as in duty bound, will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Extradition (Foreign States) Act 1966
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled.
The Petition of the undersigned residents of Australia respectfully showeth:

That the humble petitioners are gravely concerned about recent changes in the Extradition (Foreign States) Act of 1966 which deny basic rights which have been a cornerstone of the English and Australian law for over seven hundred years. We are speaking of the right to be presumed innocent until proven guilty and the right of an individual to defend himself against his accusers. This concern has come to light during recent extradition proceedings against Messrs. Hempel and Etheredge in Western Australia.

We are concerned that because judicial protection of these basic rights has been excluded from the Act, refugees, migrants, Australian overseas travellers, and visitors are at risk when they have been to (or come from) countries where the norms and practices of human rights and civil liberties are below traditionally accepted Australian standards.

We the undersigned petitioners, therefore urge the government to re-examine the Extradition (Foreign States) Act (as amended in 1985), and amend the current Act so that the rights of the accused are once again judicially protected in Australia.

In addition, we urge the government to refrain from entering into any further extradition treaties or proceedings under the current Act until the process of re-examination and amendment of the Act has occurred.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Fringe Benefits Tax
PETITION.PARA: To the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled. The humble petition of the undersigned electors of Australia respectfully showeth:
That the Government should cancel the Fringe Benefits Tax they intend to impose on businesses throughout Australia because:
1. The tax discriminates against charitable organisations, sports clubs, private schools and religious organisations.
2. The tax will mean employees around Australia will suffer reductions in their remuneration packages.
3. The Bill places another impossible burden of paperwork on small business.
4. The Bill is absurd in its application to Government employees who now constitute 32% of the workforce.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Australian Bill of Rights Bill
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives in Parliament House.
The petition of certain citizens of Australia respectfully showeth:
That the Bill of Rights is a dangerous piece of legislation which gives us no new legally enforceable rights;
That the Bill of Rights leaves out vital rights such as the right not to belong to a trade union, the right to own private property, the right to a private education;
That the Bill of Rights gives dangerous new powers to a Federal Government Commission to investigate in private, without legal representation and with criminal penalties for refusing to co-operate;
That the Bill of Rights deals with our rights; therefore we, the people, should say whether we want it by a referendum.

Your petitioners humbly pray that you repeal the Bill of Rights legislation and not restrict the individual freedoms of Australians and its present justice system, nor in any underhand way centralise power in our three tier system of Government.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Australian Bill of Rights Bill
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled. The humble petition of the undersigned citizens of Maranoa electorate respectfully showeth that:
The current Government's Bill of Rights seeks to make changes in the constitutional balance in Australia by intruding into the affairs of individuals and of State and local Governments.
Your petitioners humbly pray that the House of Representatives, in Parliament assembled, urge the Government to;

Repeal the Bill of Rights legislation and not restrict the individual freedoms of Australians and its present justice system, nor in any underhand way centralise power in our three tier system of Government.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: World Peace
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled. The humble petition of the undersigned citizens of Australia showeth:

1. That we the undersigned, who have been part of a 24 hour vigil for peace, believe that the present global arms race (both conventional and nuclear) is not part of God's plan for the human race. Consequently we urge the Australian Government to do all within its power in word and deed, locally and internationally to:
(1) further the cause of peace;
(2) curb the present arms race;
(3) promote the view that justice is the precursor of peace;
(4) acknowledge the causal relationship between arms spending and world poverty.
And your petitioners, as in duty bound, will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: First International Earth Repair Year
PETITION.PARA: For 1988 to be proclaimed the `First International Earth Repair Year' (FIERY) as an international aspect of the Australian Bicentenary activities
To the Honourable the Speaker and members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled.
This petition of concerned Australian citizens respectfully points out:

That deterioration of the total global environment is continuing at an increasing rate; that important environmental resources vital to human livelihood such as trees, soil and water are decreasing at an alarming rate; that there is a need for educating all people to assume a greater responsibility for the conservation, sustainable use and maintenance of vital resources; that dynamic and active initiatives are needed to conserve and renew the total environment; and that protecting, conserving and repairing the Earth can unite all people and nations in co-operative action for survival.

DEBATE.TITLE: WAGE INDEXATION AND REFORM OF INDUSTRIAL RELATIONS SYSTEM

DEBATE.SUB1.TITLE: Discussion of Matter of Public Importance

INTERJECT.SPEAKER: Mr DEPUTY SPEAKER

TALK.START.PARA: — Madam Speaker has received a letter from the Deputy Leader of the Opposition (Mr N.A. Brown) proposing that a definite matter of public importance be submitted to the House for discussion, namely:

INTERJECT.PARA: The Government's belated abandonment of wage indexation and its refusal to support necessary reforms to Australia's industrial relations system.
I call upon those members who approve of the proposed discussion to rise in their places.
More than the number of members required by the Standing Orders having risen in their places-

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Brown The Hon N.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —We raise this matter of public importance for three reasons: First, because the Australian people should be reminded of the economic damage that the Hawke Government has done to Australia by sticking stubbornly and against all the evidence to its policy of full indexation of wages; secondly, because the Australian people should be reminded that the Opposition set the pace in the reform of our industrial relations system and it still sets the pace for reform of that system; and thirdly, because at a time when the whole system is under review and when there is great public demand for reform, the Government is not leading or giving the direction it should be, but is stumbling around from one knee-jerk reaction to another.

SPEECH.PARA: We put the charge that the Hawke Government recklessly adopted the policy of full wage indexation in the first place. It adopted it recklessly, as the very terms of the accord mark 1 said. The accord mark 1 said that the objective of wage fixation was to ensure that wage increases did not give added impetus to inflation and unemployment. How was the accord mark 1 going to achieve that lofty objective? Believe it or not, it was to achieve it by setting in concrete a formula which was also set out in accord mark 1. That formula was to establish that:
. . . a system of full cost of living adjustments will be strongly supported.

So the Government committed itself from the very beginning to full indexation of wages. We say that that was a reckless policy from the very beginning. The proof that it was a reckless policy is now plain for all to see because the chickens the Hawke Government set loose in 1983 have now come home to roost. We have the results of what the Government started in 1983. We have higher inflation-the very thing that was warned about at the beginning-than any country with which we compare ourselves and rising unemployment. Those are the very things the accord mark 1 referred to. We have unemployment that is higher now than at any other time in the last 15 months and, as we know from the September quarter figures, we have negative employment growth. We say that the Government not only took up that policy recklessly but also pursued it recklessly against all the evidence. It pursued it recklessly despite the fact that it was warned time and time again that that was a policy that would lead this country to economic disaster.

The history of the last three and a half years has been the history of the Hawke Government blindly following a discredited policy and being dragged, kicking and screaming, to the most grudging and pathetic abandonment of indexation, but only after the damage had been done. What has been very clear during this three and a half year period is that the Opposition warned the Government time and time again of the perilous course it had embarked upon. Madam Speaker, I ask you to listen, for instance, to what the Leader of the Opposition (Mr Howard) had to say when he was shadow Treasurer. He warned the Government as early as 16 March 1984 that it was on a course of disaster. The Leader of the Opposition, the then shadow Treasurer, said:

At a time of high inflation and low competitiveness it is quite irresponsible for the Government to be blazing the trail of full wage indexation and advocating wage increases that are greater than the economy can bear.

We gave the Government a clear warning in that and many other statements made by the then shadow Treasurer. We also told the Government what it should do at the 1984 election. This is what we said in our policy document would occur under a coalition government:
Wage rises will be based not on the C.P.I.-
we could clearly see the damage that was being done-
but on the capacity of the economy to pay increases without adversely affecting employment, inflation or the competitiveness of Australian economy.

The shadow Treasurer made it plain and gave that warning; the whole Opposition made it plain and gave that warning in its policy documents in 1984. We say that we were on the right track then-the evidence supports that we were on the right track then-and we say that we are on the right track now. The Government took a very long time to learn. As all the statistics piled up against it and all the signs started to emerge of how we were going down the drain compared with other countries, this is the way the Government, in its own propaganda, summed up its great achievements, as it described them, of the first two years of the prices and incomes accord:
It is giving us record growth, it is giving us falling inflation and it is giving us dramatically rising employment.

I ask honourable members to listen to the way in which the Government denigrated other countries that had abandoned full wage indexation. It devoted a whole page of the propaganda book it put out at the time to saying how foolish were countries such as Belgium, Italy, Holland, France-it even pointed the finger at the United States of America-for abandoning wage indexation. The Government said in its propaganda book:
Most other countries have not maintained full indexation in recent times.

Of course most other countries have not maintained full wage indexation in recent times. They abandoned wage indexation for very good reasons which are now only too apparent. When all those signs of economic decay tumbled out of the sky, what did the Government do? It pressed on with accord mark 2, as if accord mark 1 had not been enough. Accord mark 2 likewise says in plain terms that wage rates will be fully adjusted in accordance with movements in prices. As if that were not enough, the Government then piled on top of our wage cost structure an extra 3 per cent for superannuation. What was the lofty objective of that absurd policy? Again, accord mark 2 tells us, because it says:
This agreement is designed to reduce the level of inflation.

That is the course upon which the Government embarked-full wage indexation and 3 per cent on top of that-and the objective is to lower inflation. One could go on and on, but the history remains the same. The history is of the Hawke Government, controlled by the trade unions as usual, pushing wage indexation on to our cost structure and sending us into an inflationary spiral and an economic suicide dive. At long last, after all the damage has been done and after the Government's lame attempts to patch up the system, the Government has come along at the midnight hour and raised the white flag. The Government has said: `All right, we will abandon wage indexation'. We want a day to write the final chapter of the last three and a half years. We say to the Government, in writing this final chapter of Australian history: `You have made a pathetic and discredited retreat after you have done enormous damage to the Australian economy, and the Australian people at their first opportunity will judge you guilty'.

As we write this chapter, let us put to bed one of the myths the Government has been peddling for so long about the achievements of the accord and wage indexation. The Government has peddled the myth that this scheme has produced wage restraint. Let me say two things about this: Firstly, the Budget Papers tell us exactly the opposite. We have been told in the Budget Papers that under the present policies we will have wage increases of over six per cent in Australia this year. The countries with which we trade will have a 4 1/2 per cent increase. Secondly, the accord has not brought down labour costs in Australia. The Government tells us that our labour costs have fallen by 7 per cent since 1982 but it does not tell us that 5 per cent of that 7 per cent reduction occurred in 1983-84 as a direct result of the previous Government's wages pause. The Government keeps trotting out these unit labour costs, which look good because Australia is now on a high inflationary kick, but if one looks at the nominal figures which are the only real test, our unit labour costs have risen by 4 per cent each year; four times the average of our major trading partners, whose labour costs have increased by only one per cent. Let us go on from here, because at long last the Government has said that it will abandon wage indexation. Abandon it in favour of what? The accord was described in this lofty way by the Treasurer (Mr Keating) as recently as 19 August in the Budget Speech when he said:
. . . the Government reaffirms its confidence in the Prices and Incomes Accord.
As recently as only two months ago the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) got up on his high horse and said this about wage indexation and the accord:
This is hardly the time to be abandoning so well tried and successful a system of wage indexation.

Is that still operative, or has it been abandoned? The Government should stand up and tell us whether it is still operative. Then the Government started floating a bi-cord, but that was not good enough for Senator Walsh; he wanted a tri-cord. We are still waiting for the lost chord. What was the contribution of the Minister for Employment and Industrial Relations (Mr Willis)? We saw him fumbling in Question Time today to try to present some sort of coherent system. His contribution is to abuse the employers and to say that it is time for them to get their act together.

We say that it is time for the Government to get its act together because at the moment the Government is floundering. Firstly, it said that it would reform the system with the recommendations of the Hancock Committee of Review of the Australian Industrial Relations Law and Systems and it would do so immediately. We learned last week that it has given away that idea and we will not see legislation based on the recommendations of the Hancock Committee. Secondly, the Government looked at the Opposition's industrial relations policy and said that it has been widely accepted in the community as the most significant blueprint for reform of industrial relations in this country. Then the Minister said that it was utterly irresponsible and unconstitutional. I defy the Minister to say that he did not say words to that effect. He said there was not a single point in it that was of any use to man or beast.

Let us look at what has happened to some of those proposals since then. We said indexation should be abandoned. That has been accepted. We said Australia should accept the need for flexibility. That has been accepted. We said that restrictive work practices should be removed by agreement by employers and employees at the work place. That has been accepted by the Government's latest mini-summit. We proposed that employees have shares in the companies in which they work. Even that has some merit according to the Prime Minister. He holds it up as some new truth which has been revealed to only him. Are those proposals still utterly irresponsible and unconstitutional now that they have been stolen by the Government? Is it unconstitutional for the trade unions now to be proposing agreements between employers and employees on wages? Instead of the fumbling that we got at Question Time today from the Minister for Employment and Industrial Relations perhaps we will now get some straight answers on these questions.

We say there are further very significant reforms needed in our industrial relations system. The Opposition is at the vanguard of the move for reform. The Government had better get its act together on reforms before it is swamped and overwhelmed by the public demand for them. The Opposition has been at the forefront of reform and it is still there. These reforms are essential if we are to have a modern industrial relations system and not one that continues to drag us down the drain as Moody's Investor Services Inc. said of Australia only a few months ago.

We give the Minister an opportunity to come back to tell us in clear, simple language whether the Government accepts our proposals and if not why. We say that Australia needs first a definite commitment to flexibility to the extent that employers and employees can make their own bargains on wages, conditions of employment and work practices. What is the Government's answer to that? Secondly, Australia needs a commitment that the capacity of industry to pay should at least be the test in national wage cases and other major wage cases. Thirdly, Australia needs a commitment that while the present system lasts and while we are working within this system there should be a wages pause. What is the Government's answer on that? Fourthly, Australia needs a commitment to put the trade unions under the same law as everyone else in the country. Fifthly and specifically, we need a commitment that the Government will not repeal or try to repeal sections 45d and 45e of the Trade Practices Act. Sixthly, we need a commitment to voluntary unionism in Australia instead of having people pushed into organisations they do not want to join. Seventhly, we need a commitment to having youth wages in awards before youth unemployment erodes any further.

We challenge the Minister to stand up to say whether the Government supports these reforms, as the Opposition does, and to say whether the Government will be dragged kicking and screaming at the last hour to support these reforms in the same way in which it has been dragged kicking and screaming to abandon wage indexation.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Willis The Hon R.

TALKER.NAME: Mr WILLIS
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Employment and Industrial Relations)

TALK.START.PARA: —Underlying the whole quarter of an hour contribution from the Deputy Leader of the Opposition, the honourable member for Menzies (Mr N.A. Brown) was the sheer falsity of his basic position and that of the Opposition in claiming that the present difficult economic circumstances are attributable to the wage indexation system that applied after this Government came to office. That is utterly and completely false, without one shred of truth in it. The fact is that whilst wage indexation continued until 1985 the economy recovered extremely well from the worst recession in 50 years, a recession which was left to us by the previous Government. That recovery enabled us to have very strong rates of employment growth and strong growth in the economy-with a wage indexation system in operation. By the end of 1984 we had reduced the inflation rate from 11 per cent to 5 per cent. When we came to office the inflation rate left to the nation by the Leader of the Opposition (Mr Howard) when he was Treasurer was 11 per cent. That was occurring with the wage indexation system operating. From 1985 that situation started to change, not because of any failure of the wages system, not because of any failure of the accord, but simply because of something which did not pass the lips of the Deputy Leader of the Opposition in his quarter hour contribution; that is, the fact that we had occurring in this country a major deterioration in the terms of trade, the like of which has not been seen certainly since the 1930s.

SPEECH.PARA: To give a speech along the lines that all the economic problems have occurred in the last year or so because of the wage indexation system is an extraordinary deception; it is a completely false charge which I think belittles the Opposition, which is trying to get the Australian people to believe something that is so patently untrue and absurd. The fact is that we have had an enormously large decline in the terms of trade, brought about by an almost cataclysmic decline in our export prices. This has brought about the devaluation of the Australian dollar, accordingly increasing import prices, accordingly pushing up the inflation rate and accordingly requiring us to adjust a number of aspects of economic policy, as the result of which we have had much lower rates of economic growth, higher inflation and some slight increase in unemployment in the last few months.

That kind of adjustment to the economy has been unavoidable. No government pursuing any conceivable wages policy could have avoided the kind of adjustment that has had to be made because of what has happened to this nation through the decline in the terms of trade. It is just absurd to produce arguments in this place or anywhere else which totally refrain from any mention of the basic underlying economic fact of our time; that is, that any government would have had to make severe adjustment.

It was that decline in the terms of trade and the consequent balance of payments problems, with devaluation reaching 20 per cent by September 1985, which forced us to the first substantial adjustment to our wages policy-that was that we had to ensure a discount of 2 per cent and the postponement of any productivity case so that we could have adjustment of wages policy and not build in a higher inflation rate. That was done through the accord. Any government without the accord would have had to impose that lower rate of wage outcome on the trade union movement by crunching the economy through the floor; by a much greater toughening of budgetary and monetary policy; by forcing economic growth down much further; by creating much more unemployment, as the Fraser Government did several times in its period of office; thereby creating the conditions in which it could have brought down inflation again.

We were able to avoid that kind of crunching of the economy because we had the accord, because we had agreement from the trade union movement of an acceptance of a lower wage outcome, a reduction in real wages and a postponement of the productivity case, on the basis of a tax tradeoff. That was uniquely available to this Government. Because of the accord, we were able to save the Australian people from much more pain than would have been their lot had they had a government with no prices and incomes accord to go back to and achieve a voluntary reduction in real wages. Indeed, before that we had already seen, with the previous full indexation system, that we had less than full wage indexation applying and that we had a reduction in real wages over the period 1983-85 of 4 per cent. So, in our first three years in office we had a reduction in real wages of 4 per cent. That came about partly because of the way in which the full indexation system operated and partly because of the September adjustment.

Since September 1985 and since that very substantial contribution by the trade union movement to the betterment of the Australian economy by voluntarily accepting a reduction in real wages, we have had a further 20 per cent devaluation of the Australian dollar broadly. We had that because of the further deterioration of the terms of trade and the further balance of payments problems. The need, therefore, is for us to make further adjustment to the Australian economy. That has required us further to tighten monetary policy, to toughen budgetary policy further and to seek further discounting on wages policy.

These are the basic elements that face the Government at present and it is in that situation that we now look forward to a system, if the indexation system continues, of only partial wage indexation. It is not open to us to have anything like full wage indexation in the next national wage case or the case after that because of the present economic imperative that we have a reduction in real wages so that we do not build in the higher inflation rate being foisted on us by devaluations and so that we adjust to the reduction in living standards which is being forced on us as a nation by those devaluations.

The wages system that we have pursued has enabled us to do that with minimal pain. What we are about is continuing to have a wages system that will enable us to implement the appropriate overall wages policy with minimal pain to the Australian people, with the minimum amount of unemployment growth and the minimum amount of reduction in real income. That is being done now by further discussions between the Government and the Australian Council of Trade Unions and also between the Government and the employers on the way in which we should be further developing that wages policy. As I said during Question Time, we are concerned that the continuance of a partial wage indexation system, which on the face of it should be delivering full wage indexation, becomes very difficult, yet the economic requirement is for the continuance of partial indexation. Given that that is the economic requirement, we believe that it is probably appropriate that we change the system to one which has a much greater chance of remaining sustainable and of giving us the overall outcomes that are economically necessary.

We also see some value in taking that course in that, given the requirement for a low overall wage outcome, with a partial wage indexation system there would be not much scope for increasing the degree of wages flexibility. As we have said constantly, that is something that we should gradually be trying to develop and we believe that that scope will be increased if we now move to a system which moves away from wage indexation but which still provides for a basic national wage increase to apply.

It is not appropriate for me to detail now the aspects of that wages policy which is being considered by us, but we will be discussing it next week with the ACTU and with the employers. From initial discussions that I have already had with them, I am confident that we will see considerable agreement forthcoming from both the unions and the employers as to the shape of the wage fixing system that should apply into the future. I believe that is a very welcome development. We will probably not have exact agreement about everything and we will probably not be in agreement about the wage outcome, but there will be agreement about the general direction and style of the wage fixing system, and I believe that is an important development.

That, of course, has nothing to do with the nonsense we hear from the other side, repeated again today-a nonsense which I must say I continue to be amazed at. Perhaps after all this time I should not be, but I am just amazed at the sheer ignorance which continues to come forth from the Opposition, particularly its spokesman on industrial relations, as to various industrial relations matters. The Deputy Leader of the Opposition has tried to suggest that the Government is stealing the Opposition's clothes. Let me say that in developing our wages policy, the last thing we would have regard to is anything said by the Opposition. We are developing a wages policy that is appropriate to our time. That is what we have had all the way along-a wages policy that has been conducive to growth and conducive to the necessary adjustment that we have faced as a result of the enormous decline in our terms of trade. We are continuing to develop a wages policy that is appropriate to the economic times we face, and what we need now is a policy which is appropriate to the economic recovery which is clearly getting under way again and which will become strong in 1987.

The Opposition has said that we are taking notice of its policy in respect of such things as voluntary agreements. I regard that part of the Opposition's policy as absurdly unrealistic. Indeed, the Opposition's whole wages policy is a disgrace in the sense that it makes no attempt at any wage restraint. It simply says: Let everyone get out there and do his own thing and we hope that that produces the appropriate outcome. Of course, that is a highly irresponsible stance to adopt, but also the Opposition is adopting a policy the basis of which, frankly, as I have said before, is simply unconstitutional. We are developing a wages policy within existing legislation. We do not need to change any legislation to develop the appropriate system for wage fixation. Although changes will be forthcoming in respect of the Hancock legislation, legislation is not necessary to change the wage system.

The Opposition is talking about changes to legislation to provide for voluntary agreements, but these would be without a constitutional base. The Constitution does not allow for legislation for voluntary agreements, whether or not an interstate or industrial dispute exists, yet the Opposition bases its policy on that approach. The Constitution does not allow for legislation for agreements other than those which would allow for dispute settlement by conciliation and arbitration. That, of course, is what the Opposition proposes. The Constitution does not allow for legislation requiring agreements to contain specified provisions such as the provision that there shall be the award rate of pay. The Constitution does not allow legislation to prohibit the Australian Conciliation and Arbitration Commission having regard to voluntary agreements. Finally, the Constitution does not allow legislation to require the Commission to set aside existing awards.

On all of these bases the Opposition's policy is constitutionally invalid. If the Opposition says `We have a great industrial relations policy', in the absence of a wages policy, and it is based on a series of measures which are unconstitutional, it is impossible to take much notice of it. In developing our industrial relations policy we do not take any notice of the Opposition. Our policy is one which has been developed to suit the needs of the time. The wages policy adjustment is one that will be appropriate and will have widespread support. The industrial relations changes that we shall bring forward will also have that widespread support. They have been developed in conjunction with the trade union movement and organised employers.

The basis of the industrial relations policy that has been developed by this Government is an emphasis on co-operation rather than confrontation. The Opposition's policy, as we have seen from the past, is one of confrontation. Indeed, the Opposition, especially the Deputy Leader of the Opposition, is supporting the madder elements that are calling for a massively confrontationist approach. Everyone knows that if the Opposition were to get back into power we would see an enormous industrial relations explosion as it pursued policies that were bound to create an enormous amount of industrial disputation. The Australian people do not want that. They want a government which has an appropriate wages policy and an effective industrial relations policy. That is what they have had from this Government, and that is what they will continue to get.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Wright Mr K.W.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister for Arts, Heritage and Environment, upon notice, on 2 May 1986:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) What role is played by the Federal Government in the protection of Australia's beaches and coastline from erosion.
(2) What has been the total Federal expenditure in this area in each year since 1972.
(3) How do the Federal and State governments co-operate in this area.

Areas in which the Commonwealth has undertaken major programs of preventative maintenance and restoration on the coast include: Beecroft and Bherwerre Peninsulas (Jervis Bay, NSW); Sandy Point (Western Port Bay, Victoria); Garden Island (Fremantle, Western Australia); Fort Direction (Hobart, Tasmania) Portsea (Mornington Peninsula, Victoria); and Swanbourne (Perth, Western Australia).

The Commonwealth, Territory and State governments also co-operate on coastal management matters through the Community Employment Program and the Local Government Development Program.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

ANSWER.PARA: To my knowledge, no progress has been made in the establishment of a pilot national injury surveillance and prevention system for deaths and injuries associated with only consumer products in mind.
